Check out what's going on with it on the \"About\" page from the main menu."}},{"id":"QBOY_zs6_K","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"If you're interested in contributing, reach out to grady.b.ward@gmail.com and I'll give you a login. High level and directional feedback is very welcome at the same address."}},{"id":"8DaZ5KZlKZ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Thanks!"}},{"id":"TPDKIHK5aC","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Grady"}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Text: Minimize digital harms through design, a guide for product managers and regulators.

attributes.RichText: {"time":1688859689713,"blocks":[{"id":"unbR1SD1f8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though digital platforms have unlocked many benefits, they have also enabled new (and exacerbated old) forms of harm. Understanding the broad similarities and subtle distinctions between these abusive behaviors can help you better regulate and mitigate them."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}
{"time":1688861414771,"blocks":[{"id":"ji_m8uGKBx","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"An interactive guide, by Grady Ward, a visiting fellow at the Integrity Institute."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1689973846660,"blocks":[{"id":"fYob5NPUBa","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While there are a near-infinite number of interventions that platforms could undertake to reduce abuse on their services, these tend to fit into a small number of common themes that we call \"Intervention Categories\". Developing an understanding of these fundamental building blocks (through which interventions and regulation can be built) has a number of advantages over focusing on specific interventions:"}},{"id":"_rDRGLb4np","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Estimation: Intervention Categories have common strengths and weaknesses, so they're great abstract tools for considering the potential of given approach for mitigating a given harm.","Future-Facing: Because the techniques are useful across forms of abuse, they can be used as a starting point for figuring out how to tackle emergent harms.","Composition: Since they can be used together, sophisticated organizations will often use heavily hybridized approaches, which can be hard to understand if not explained in terms of these approach-based ideas."]}},{"id":"XxZewPNsF1","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"We write at length about each of these \"Intervention Categories\" because they represent the most helpful piece of the puzzle: not just ideas for how to build platforms that are more resilient today, but a Swiss army knife of strategies that engineers, product managers, and regulators can keep in mind as they navigate today's harms and plan for those of tomorrow."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1689975063977,"blocks":[{"id":"fGJxaPbszQ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platform design has the transformational capacity to shape (and reshape) the digital ecosystems in which we exist. A well chosen set of principles and approaches can allow platforms to simultaneously build user trust, and increase their public perception as a place where users' interests are respected and their safety is guaranteed. A poorly designed set of features has the potential to erode user loyalty and trust, and degrade the brand of an online space into irrelevance. "}},{"id":"Y-y1Td96ln","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Intervention Design is the creative re-imagination of how platforms could operate in the future, and it's an imaginative exercise that puts legislators, regulators, and every-day users into the seat of product manager: how should the platform work, and what are the trade-offs implied by that design?"}},{"id":"17Uy2jQNFM","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This exercise is far from hypothetical. Most of the interventions listed by this site could be demanded by users, enforced through legislation, or required by regulators. "}},{"id":"pFHMM8K0HL","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Once we have the ability to imagine a better internet, we will find the power to build it."}},{"id":"tzybDTCq4X","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This page features a long list of ideas of how platforms could change. Though most of these will probably sound too radical, too technical, or too invasive to seem realistic to you,  I suspect a few will seem exiting, impactful, and possible - and if a better internet is just a few ideas away, what could you do to make it happen?"}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1689978714349,"blocks":[{"id":"nUJNq5-uGn","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The internet has opened up a vast landscape of potential online harms. Often, these harms are a direct translation of real-world abuse into digital spaces, revealing how deeply rooted societal ills can permeate even novel spaces. In other cases, the internet poses unique, digital-native harms, underscoring the profound ways the internet's connectivity and ubiquity can reshape our world, and sometimes do so for the worse. "}},{"id":"Ebh6N-fpkq","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The public discussion around online harms has focused on Content Moderation. This approach is fractally fraught, and ultimately (I think) not a good tool for fixing most harms. Content moderation is time consuming, contentious, politically-fraught, and requires constant oversight and rule building. While it might seem like the right tool to reach for when content generates harm on the internet, it's helpful to back up and ask: what about the platform makes harmful content prevalent?
"}},{"id":"I3PanrWE2m","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While the digital platforms themselves are not often directly to blame for these abuses, their design, algorithms, and policies often facilitate or exacerbate harm. By digging into why platforms are potential conduits for harm, this project explores how platforms could be tweaked by their owners, regulated by their governments, or petitioned by their users for redesigns that center harm aversion."}},{"id":"l-gFqbL5u9","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"To get started, pick one of the harms below that you're most concerned with."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1688859741969,"blocks":[{"id":"IU4ktJXtUA","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Historically, we've looked to content moderation to clean up after abuse. But reacting to user content or behavior is expensive, contentious, and happens only after the harm is done. We can do better, by designing features to be less abuse-able, and regulating away the features most likely to cause harm."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1698122621894,"blocks":[{"id":"4BepZrUAEC","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though we might think of the cause of Online Harms as bad content or bad behavior, the systemic cause is typically the design of the features of the platform, including the platform's business model."}},{"id":"SdHZWZAO8A","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Seeing these connections can help product managers build platforms that are less capable of being abused, and help regulators see the elements of platforms that can be uniformly described and regulated."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1698262831749,"blocks":[{"id":"1t7fKfKTZE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though online abuse mirrors the variety and complexity of real-world abuse, the motivations of online actors enacting some kind of harm can be categorized into a relatively small number of broad categories."}},{"id":"M4PhC6g-gr","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Understanding each of these categories is essential to building the counter-abuse protections that can defend against them. Financially motivated actors will invest time and resources in understanding your platform's defenses. Sexually motivated actors may pursue their objectives without concern for their being caught. Personally motivated actors typically lack the technical sophistication of other abusers. These are just a few generalizations that can be made when thinking about online abuse through the lens of actor motivation."}},{"id":"h5DMQw72Mt","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Browsing through the abuse types that are motivated by a given goal, and you are certain to find structural commonalities in harm, that when synthesized, have the power to generate analogies toward solvency."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1698735960686,"blocks":[{"id":"r7IFANNjRF","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While internet platforms might look like they're incredibly complex, in reality there are a small number of fundamental features that are common across platforms. This commonality exists because we as users struggle to adopt different tools on different platforms. Instead, we become accustomed to a few standard ways of interacting with platform services, and carry this understanding with us as we traverse the internet. Platforms design for this preference, building features based on patterns already in use elsewhere, which has the effect of homogenizing functionality across platforms. This reuse and standardization of features benefits users, making sites easier to navigate. It also reveals common vulnerabilities and patterns of abusive behavior across platforms."}},{"id":"ft9RGuBi_D","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The name of this site (Focus on Features) stems from this observation. While platforms are more numerous than we could possibly grapple with individually, the features that platforms create are both small in number and vehicles along which abuse can be consistently identified, analyzed and stymied."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

{"time":1698264165501,"blocks":[{"id":"a1RLQGQld8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In the security, privacy, and counter-abuse professions, the term threat modeling describes the process of identifying, assessing, and addressing potential threats to a system. This process starts by answering two questions: \"how can our system be abused\" and \"who would want to abuse us in that way\". Understanding the who is critical because different entities have wildly different levels of technical sophistication, adaptability, patience and resources to dedicate to their objective. For example:"}},{"id":"1cx0NdHNFA","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Considering the actor enables platforms to gauge the sufficiency of their mitigations by comparing the alignment of the strengths of their interventions with the strengths of the adversary. An intervention that leverages a pay-gate will not prove effective against an actor like a nation state with ample access to financial resources.","The actor also largely informs whether or not state intervention may be advisable. Legislation or regulation targeted at large corporations is likely to see a high degree of compliance, whereas state interventions that target hostile foreign adversaries or unsuspecting individuals are less likely to be effective."]}},{"id":"Xhf_bvm1ZW","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These are just two examples of how looking at abuse through the actor can be a powerful vantage point. As you look through each collection, note the similarities in mechanism, cause, and motivation in the harms that these actors are responsible for."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comments
attributes.Definition: Expressions of response to either some primary content, or other comments.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698212163692,"blocks":[{"id":"7ql-4YDjit","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Comment sections are a secondary component of a web page in which users can discuss a primary source of media. These systems provide an easy way for users to interact with the author and fellow commenters, fostering a participatory online environment, and at their best, enabling the exchange of ideas. Unfortunately, comment sections are perhaps best known for the ways in which they are consistently abused."}},{"id":"dzGjbm5x2I","type":"header","data":{"text":"Abuse of comments comes from their design","level":2}},{"id":"CrbiPeFCUe","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The frequency with which comments are abused comes from a few sources of their common implementation and design:"}},{"id":"pZJ0oSKhh1","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Comments are typically public, which encourages performative behavior of all kinds, including the nastier varieties.","Comments are viewed as low stakes, since typically they are secondary to the primary content of the site, which encourages less thoughtful engagement, and feels less consequential to the commenter.","Comments are often paired with scores and voting, which inculcates competitive one-upsmanship and encourages \"Dunking\".","Because comments spread context across multiple entities (replies, threads, primary content), they're harder to moderate through classifiers."]}},{"id":"48avW4YXnb","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"By reevaluating comment system design, product managers can mitigate challenges faced by platforms and discourage abusive user behavior."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Spam
attributes.Definition: Unsolicited solicitations with commercial or promotional intent.

attributes.Title: Amplifies, exacerbating a tendency to harm
Trolling
attributes.Definition: Posting disingenuous provocative messages to intentional elicit emotional reactions.

attributes.Title: Harassment / Cyberbullying
attributes.Definition: Unwanted and repeated behavior that threatens, annoys, or intimidates a victim.

attributes.Title: Feedback bombing
attributes.Definition: Attempting to manipulate perception of an entity through large volumes of inauthentic feedback.

attributes.Title: Omit comment reaction volume
attributes.Definition: Don't prominently display the number of likes or other forms of feedback a comment gets.

attributes.Title: Posting Limits
attributes.Definition: Limit the volume of information a user can generate in a day.

attributes.Title: Comment Ordering
attributes.Definition: Set the tone for the conversation by choosing the order in which voices are heard.

attributes.Title: Affinity To Comment
attributes.Definition: Require a history of interaction between users before they're allowed to interact in comments.

attributes.Title: Allow immediate location takedown
attributes.Definition: Enable any user to immediately censor a physical address from public content.

attributes.Title: Temporal Comment Limits
attributes.Definition: Restricting the volume of comments people can post will make folks think twice about their actions.

attributes.Title: Feedback Only From Authoritative Sources
attributes.Definition: Allow users with geographic proximity, purchase history, or other signals of engagement to leave ratings.

attributes.Title: Don't allow posting of Location
attributes.Definition: Use content filters to prevent users from posting addresses, latitude/longitude coordinates, or other location data.

attributes.Title: Comment Tone Check Popup
attributes.Definition: Before posting content containing vulgarities, prompt a user to think twice.

attributes.Title: API Surface Area
attributes.Definition: Prevent automated access to features that are intended only for human activity.

attributes.Title: Auto-Generated Content Quiz
attributes.Definition: Encourage users to dig deeper than headlines by validating their knowledge of the subject.

attributes.Title: No Comments for Fresh Accounts
attributes.Definition: Don't accept comments from newly created or barely used accounts.

attributes.Title: Author Comment-Moderation
attributes.Definition: Enable primary content creators control over the comments layered on their content.

attributes.Title: Reporting Mechanisms
attributes.Definition: Allow users to flag content or behavior that they find to be abusive.

attributes.Title: Label identical content
attributes.Definition: For some types of harm, the same data a strong signal of something being off.

attributes.Title: Three Insult Rule
attributes.Definition: Rather than looking at whether individual pieces of content constitute harassment, consider patterns of behavior.

attributes.Title: Read before Comment
attributes.Definition: Require users to read the primary content before they leave comments.

attributes.Title: Identity
attributes.Definition: Individuals' ability to represent themselves in a digital space.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698212819653,"blocks":[{"id":"L7IhWgzOjQ","type":"header","data":{"text":"Identity is self representation","level":2}},{"id":"E-K1DGlfBH","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Identity in online platforms refers to the basket of personal information users provide in presenting themselves online. We often think of this as a username and a profile picture, but since users can often represent any part of themselves in a platform, Identity can encompass a wide range of personal attributes, including gender, religion, sexual orientation, location, education, interests, and any other number of affiliations or identities that a user may or may not hold in the real world."}},{"id":"jBqyPdvnb-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The degree to which platforms structure the elements of user identity varies across a broad spectrum, in line with the degree to which the online persona is expected to be a representation of a real world person. At one end, identity on dating apps tends to be highly structured in order to give users powerful features by which to filter and sort prospective matches, and users are expected to provide accurate data so as not to dissemble to potential dates. At the other end of the spectrum, identity on publishing sites like blogs tends to be optional and freeform, even anonymous, and is broadly understood to be potentially unrepresentative of the human behind the profile."}},{"id":"ENv0md-wgR","type":"header","data":{"text":"Anonymity plays an important role on the internet","level":2}},{"id":"EwtAlncynI","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Identity is an important tool for building trust on the internet, but it isn't well suited for all tasks. Anonymity, it's shadow, plays a different set of critical functions."}},{"id":"vLMt5IGVIe","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Anonymitiy safeguards freedom of expression and protects individuals' privacy and safety. It allows folks to openly express their opinions, ideas, and concerns without fear of retaliation or persecution. It empowers marginalized and vulnerable groups to voice their perspectives, share sensitive information, and participate in public discussions without the fear of retaliation. It also enables whistleblowers, activists, and individuals living under oppressive regimes to communicate and advocate for change without risking retaliation. Anonymity is a valuable feature that empowers everyone to live more freely online - with fewer real world consequences for online actions."}},{"id":"QJaZeJR2BZ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Designing platform identity (setting the structural expectations for user representation on a platform) simultaneously designs anonymity on the platform. Most platforms enable some forms of both identity and anonymity, a balancing act in line with their broader trade-offs between trust and freedom."}},{"id":"SIUFUVK0S1","type":"header","data":{"text":"Abuses in Identity","level":2}},{"id":"mcEejrlzbJ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"As with any powerful tool facilitating a physical connection with the digital world, identity is a common font of abuse. "}},{"id":"UwBeY0EOyy","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Privacy broadly describes one basket of concerns. When users provide personal information to a platform, it is immediately at risk to unauthorized access, data breaches, or unexpected use. With access to even limited identity features, platforms and adversarial actors can correlate identity across sites, potentially gaining access to more information than the user wanted them to be able to. Platforms also often use (or predict) a user's identity features in order to collect data for targeted advertising and discriminatory pricing."}},{"id":"5lOVzAhkqs","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Malicious misuse captures another set of concerns. The abundance of identity collection online exposes folks that submit identity information to platforms more susceptible to harm from malicious users, including doxxing, stalking, and identity theft. The novel field of \"Open Source Intelligence\" has sprung up as a result of the bounty of data-detritus that each of us leaves in our wake as we surf across the internet.  Just as OSINT experts can solve cases of international espionage, OSINT novices can often find enough information to track, steal from, and threaten ordinary citizens."}},{"id":"IDS3zmbUvs","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A final basket of concerns is the way that identity features challenge authentication: how do we know that someone is who they claim that they are online, and how can we extend trust over the internet if we don't know who people are?"}},{"id":"frYLDbLv3c","type":"header","data":{"text":"Design Identity with Empathy","level":2}},{"id":"TEyBXz7Xtq","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Because Identity sits at the bridge between the real world and the digital one, it's one of the most important ones to design for deliberately, because poor design can yield physical harm. In particular, when thinking about a feature or a use case, Product Managers should always picture their product through a diverse collection of viewpoints:"}},{"id":"UOzovvVfcd","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Could a political dissident use this tool?","Would a person with a stalker feel comfortable using this tool?","How would a tyrant use this tool?"]}},{"id":"JS0icAtW5r","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"And ask themselves a series of always useful questions:"}},{"id":"Ly-tRRTfGx","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Do we have a business need for this data?","Does this data need to be public?","What goes wrong if a user is impersonated?"]}},{"id":"X9asKRHXwx","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Well designed identity features have the potential to keep users safer, and more comfortable, in digital spaces."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.RelationshipDescription: Correlating sensitive information about a person with their real-world persona is increasingly possible when online tracking records identity features.

attributes.Title: Blackmail
attributes.Definition: Using threats of disclosure to coerce a victim.

attributes.RelationshipDescription: Unverified representation of identity is the core feature on which impersonation is possible.

attributes.Title: Impersonation
attributes.Definition: Deceptively assuming the identity of a real person.

attributes.Title: Location Misuse
attributes.Definition: Malicious use of geo-location data to stalk, harass, or harm.

attributes.Title: Discrimination
attributes.Definition: Targeting or excluding individuals in online spaces based on a protected or immutable characteristic.

attributes.Title: Online Shaming
attributes.Definition: Using the internet to publicly shame or ridicule.

attributes.Title: Swatting
attributes.Definition: Making false reports to emergency services in order to bring a victim into confrontation with law enforcement.

attributes.Title: Identity Theft
attributes.Definition: Stealing credentials or other personal information, typically for financial impersonation.

attributes.Title: Stalking
attributes.Definition: Persistent, unwanted surveillance of an individual, often causing fear and distress.

attributes.Title: Catfishing
attributes.Definition: Intentionally deceiving others about who you are, typically on dating platforms.

attributes.Title: Creates, constructing and causing the harm
Profile Building
attributes.Definition: Collecting and collating information about a user from across the internet in order to create a representational model of their interests and attitudes.

attributes.Title: Account Hijacking
attributes.Definition: Unauthorized takeover of someone else's account.

attributes.Title: Harassment / Cyberbullying
attributes.Definition: Unwanted and repeated behavior that threatens, annoys, or intimidates a victim.

attributes.Title: Squatting
attributes.Definition: Collecting high value usernames for resale, ransom or confusion, rather than for use.

attributes.Title: Account Resale
attributes.Definition: Selling stolen account credentials to enable users to assume new identities.

attributes.RelationshipDescription: A user self-representing their true identity (or being compelled to do so by a platform) is a prerequisite to doxxing.

attributes.Title: Doxxing
attributes.Definition: Divulging someone's personal information, like location, in order to harass them.

attributes.Title: Two-Factor Authentication
attributes.Definition: Authenticating users through two types of credentials (something you have, something you know, something you are).

attributes.Title: Identity Verification
attributes.Definition: Require users to register for an application with a state issued identity document.

attributes.Title: Cross platform username verification
attributes.Definition: To create an account with a popular username, require proof of ownership on another platform.

attributes.Title: Limit account volume
attributes.Definition: Reducing the volume of accounts a person can create restricts their capacity to cause harm at scale.

attributes.Title: Don't collect location data
attributes.Definition: Limit storage, retention, and sharing of location information including IP address.

attributes.Title: Delete Abandoned Accounts
attributes.Definition: Prevent high-value usernames from being squatted on by periodically cleaning up inactive accounts.

attributes.Title: Require unleaked passwords
attributes.Definition: During signup, don't allow users to use a password that has been included in a leaked dataset.

attributes.Title: User Submitted Reviews
attributes.Definition: Platforms that enable repeat engagement can benefit from allowing users to learn about the past experiences of other users.

attributes.Title: Use an OAuth Provider
attributes.Definition: Centralize identity management + risk with a company that thinks about it full time.

attributes.Title: Reporting Mechanisms
attributes.Definition: Allow users to flag content or behavior that they find to be abusive.

attributes.Title: Bulk Location Takedown Tools
attributes.Definition: Allow a user to scrub their profile of location data while leaving other data intact.

attributes.Title: Deprioritize User Identity
attributes.Definition: In platforms where the identity of the participants isn't central, omit it.

attributes.Title: Anonymous Limitations
attributes.Definition: Require users to create an account before they can use features that create data or interact with others.

attributes.Title: Subscriptions
attributes.Definition: Allows a user to request they receive another channel's novel content.
attributes.Description: {"time":1689632319485,"blocks":[{"id":"tFTdYV6N40","type":"header","data":{"text":"What are subscriptions?","level":2}},{"id":"8qj6ttEPEt","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Subscriptions are a versatile and widely utilized feature that enable users to establish persistent connections with feeds of content in order to receive new content from those feeds.Though social media is the clearest exasdfasdfmple of this bundle of features, this pattern of interaction is quite common across the rest of the internet. Feeds of content are often associated with individual content creators, but that's just one possibility among many. A few examples of the subscription/feed dynamic:"}},{"id":"6a9Gi-vz0i","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Podcast players allow users to subscribe to podcast channels."]}},{"id":"nPiacSlNm4","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Real estate systems allow users to \"save their searches\", notifying them when novel content matches their preferences."]}},{"id":"FEQIqGVY92","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Media streaming platforms allow users to follow artists, to be notified when they release new music / videos.","RSS feeds allow users to aggregate posts from their favorite sites, including blogs and news media.","Message boards often feature the ability to subscribe to new messages on the board, or to subscribe to responses to specific threads."]}},{"id":"zO0HSx3wcF","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though these are diverse sets of functionality, they all have a basic idea in common: a user taking a proactive action (subscription) that acts as a persistent request to receive new content from a well-defined source (feed)."}},{"id":"OK8KuTOfGE","type":"header","data":{"text":"Why are subscriptions useful to the internet?","level":2}},{"id":"xRDXpuyWHY","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Subscriptions offer a convenient way for users to receive relevant and timely content through a unified interface for consumption. This provides users explicit mechanisms for marking content as of interest to them, and gives them the power to spend more time consuming content, and less time discovering it."}},{"id":"7QAARnbFbu","type":"header","data":{"text":"What about sorting?","level":2}},{"id":"oicDsXJ9DX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though subscriptions may appear to be a neutral interface through which a platform gives full control to users, in reality, their impact is often heavily influenced by the algorithms that platforms use in deciding what content to show the user first."}},{"id":"q2g_JuoqOC","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Is a newsletter from a real-estate search service showing listings by the most expensive, most recent, or most heavily viewed?","Is a podcast app showing you episodes by which ones you're most likely to listen to, or which ones they have a paid partnership with?","Do you see posts on social media in chronological order, or by likelihood that you'll interact with them?"]}},{"id":"ws9-cUCYRX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In the finer details of sorting we see all of the same problems that we see arise with Recommendation, since in both cases, the prerogatives of the platform are given primacy over the prerogatives of the user. Because of the similarities between those harms, we can join those together, and cover them under that topic."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Coordinated Inauthentic Activity
attributes.Definition: Manipulating online platforms through coordinated creation of inaccurate data.

attributes.Title: Addiction
attributes.Definition: Employing strategies to encourage users to engage with more frequency and investment than the user would prefer.

attributes.Title: Amplifies, exacerbating a tendency to harm

attributes.RelationshipDescription: Users will tend to subscribe to content that aligns with their pre-existing beliefs.

attributes.Title: Echo Chamber
attributes.Definition: The unconscious tendency for people to surround themselves with media that align with their existing views.

attributes.Title: Political Misinformation
attributes.Definition: Spreading false or misleading information to influence political attitudes and outcomes.

attributes.Title: Artificial Intimacy
attributes.Definition: The creation of an a unidirectional emotional connection, often for manipulation.

attributes.Title: Limited Number of Subscriptions
attributes.Definition: By limiting the number of subscribers (or the number of subscriptions), a platform can design toward real-world connections, and away from exponential scale distributions.

attributes.Title: Hide Interaction Counts
attributes.Definition: Foster authentic interaction by making numerical properties less central.

attributes.Title: Posting Limits
attributes.Definition: Limit the volume of information a user can generate in a day.

attributes.Title: Uniform Reach
attributes.Definition: Vary posting limitations in line with subscriber volume to achieve a uniform capacity to generate impressions

attributes.Title: All Subscriptions Reciprocal
attributes.Definition: Require "following" to be bidirectional to avoid an exponential distribution of reach and attention.

attributes.Title: User-Defined Subscription Sorting
attributes.Definition: Enable users multiple different options for how to prioritize and filter content from their subscriptions.

attributes.Title: Self-imposed time limits
attributes.Definition: Allow users to set hard cutoffs on platform use.

attributes.Title: Mix in Authoritative Content
attributes.Definition: Add authoritative content from trusted partners on topics users are subscribed to.

attributes.Title: Request to Follow
attributes.Definition: Make Following a two-sided operation, so that celebs have implicit limits on the ability of fans to follow them.

attributes.Title: Third repost has to manually enter the content
attributes.Definition: Slow the spread of vitality by adding friction on repost/re-share functionality.

attributes.Title: Periodic Preference Reset
attributes.Definition: Regularly reset the profile used to generate recommendations for a user.

attributes.Title: Feedback Aggregation
attributes.Definition: Collecting user feedback, and condensing it into quantitative scores.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698213713183,"blocks":[{"id":"HwTkk0OMg-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Feedback Aggregation comprises a system that collects myriad individual user inputs and condenses them into a single, quantitative score. It is widely used across the internet to enable platforms to delegate the task of ranking and suggesting content. Rather than building intricate systems for evaluating and ranking content, platforms can leverage the collective insights of their users. This crowdsourced wisdom can often yield reliable average recommendations, be it for content, places, or ideas."}},{"id":"3J6RlBUASf","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"However, like all systems where one user can influence the actions or experience of others, feedback aggregation is susceptible to manipulation and abuse. Bad actors can game the system, skewing results to their favor, be it through spamming positive reviews for their products or disparaging competitors. Furthermore, these aggregated scores, while providing a general consensus, often fail to address the needs of specialized or niche requirements - being recommended content sorted by averages can be anti-helpful for a user with non-average requirements, like mobility issues."}},{"id":"vdVoupWL1c","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"When it is appropriately protected, and combined with other sets of features (like filtering, and structured feedback), Feedback Aggregation can represent the best of the internet: a decentralization of authority that yields collective wisdom at scale."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Coordinated Inauthentic Activity
attributes.Definition: Manipulating online platforms through coordinated creation of inaccurate data.

attributes.Title: Amplifies, exacerbating a tendency to harm
Addiction
attributes.Definition: Employing strategies to encourage users to engage with more frequency and investment than the user would prefer.

attributes.Title: Amplifies, exacerbating a tendency to harm
Feedback bombing
attributes.Definition: Attempting to manipulate perception of an entity through large volumes of inauthentic feedback.

attributes.Title: Feedback Only From Authoritative Sources
attributes.Definition: Allow users with geographic proximity, purchase history, or other signals of engagement to leave ratings.

attributes.Title: Require Physical Validation
attributes.Definition: Before leaving a review, require a photo of the reviewed entity.

attributes.Title: Weight Reviews
attributes.Definition: Use the quality of previous recommendations to weight feedback across users.

attributes.Title: Flatten Virality Curves
attributes.Definition: Cap the attention a user can receive by a multiple of their prior reach.

attributes.RelationshipDescription: Because gamifying feedback aggregation is harder if it's opaque:

attributes.Title: Recommendation
attributes.Definition: A platform proactively inserting content into a user's view.
attributes.Description: {"time":1689626612594,"blocks":[{"id":"vvqJPFMFxy","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Content recommendation on the internet refers to the use of algorithms and data analysis by online platforms to deliver personalized content to users based on their individual preferences, interests, and browsing behavior. Critically, recommendations are not in response to a preceding or historical user request - the platform offers them proactively, either in a user's primary view of the content of the site, or as a standalone \"discovery\" feature on the site."}},{"id":"uuLTT4ThhN","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"For recommendations to be accurate, platforms have to invest in significant data mining, profiling, and predictive modeling efforts, so they're technically challenging for all but the largest online platforms to build well. But for the platforms that are able to make these investments and build this infrastructure, they have developed a hugely impactful tool: the capacity to turn existing user engagement into more user engagement - the key to unlocking a spiral of engagement. When platforms can offer relevant content to users before they explicitly seek it, or even know it is something they might want, they've inverted the relationship between user and platform: now the platform decides what to use the user's attention for, rather than the user deciding how they want to use the platform."}},{"id":"3jyMNgX9Rx","type":"header","data":{"text":"Where is content recommendation?","level":2}},{"id":"f2NUxxQqri","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The most common places we see content recommendation are in the contexts of advertising and content discovery. In both of these worlds, the end goal is to increase platform engagement as measured through clicks, time on page, or other metrics of engagement, and because these goals are narrowly defined, the problem space is well adapted to machine learning techniques."}},{"id":"sZAG2yPY9v","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"However, there are much less sophisticated, and much more ubiquitous uses of recommendation across the web. Recommended connections on social networks, autoplay at the end of a playlist, trending hashtags, each of these is an example where a platform is proactively suggesting content to a user in order to induce behavior or attention."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698221521841,"blocks":[{"id":"wYVZZ07Sus","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While much of the internet's functionality can be represented in the browser through images, text, and video, file and link sharing are an essential component of online platforms that enable collaboration, aggregation or organization."}},{"id":"dlPxxqH41i","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Of primary concern with link and file sharing is the way that extracting content out of a browser exposes the user to additional risks that the perimeter of a browser and the platform usually constrains, first and foremost being Malware and its sub-variants. But file sharing also brings along with it other risks, like the storage and distribution of illegal material like CSAM, and the abuse of storage capacity."}},{"id":"Bs5Ftmomnn","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Files and links might seem at first to be distinct categories of ideas, but since links can be used to initiate a file download from a browser automatically, integrity issues around links can be viewed as a superset of integrity issues around files. Links also have two wrinkles to them that complicate their effective moderation. Firstly, the owner of the linked-to-page can change where a link goes or what it shows dynamically, without changing the link's value (i.e. a link to \"bestofbuys.co\" could redirect to Best Buy today, and a malware site tomorrow). Secondly, the linked content may go to a page which violates the community standards of the platform, but this leaves platforms in a tricky spot - should they try to enforce their standards extraterritorially by not showing links to sites that show content that is against their TOS, or should they enable this one-click sidestep of their rules. "}},{"id":"ZY_B6shc0L","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"There are few easy answers when it comes to links and files, but a few small interventions can dramatically limit the surface area that platforms leave open for harm."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698220560078,"blocks":[{"id":"JWDdtHB8I5","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Where there is money, there is likely to be abuse."}},{"id":"V5SirtyvNs","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platforms that facilitate or enable the transfer of fungible value in any form, be it hard currency, cryptocurrency, stocks, or even in-game-items, are likely to have a wide swathe of potential abuses, but these generally fall into a few categories:"}},{"id":"Vg2RRJ6akw","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Security: Attackers on trying to steal credentials, find security vulnerabilities, and otherwise assume system control that they shouldn't have access to.","Illegal Payments: Facilitation of payments for real-world criminal or other unsavory business, like money laundering, sex trafficking, directing funds to listed entities, etc.","Impersonation: users dissembling their identities to try to trick, coerce, or otherwise defraud one another.","Scams: when peer to peer payments are possible, scams come with the territory, and are often near impossible to distinguish via content alone from legitimate commerce."]}},{"id":"CSCcI46vdP","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Payments bring along with them a swathe of headaches for organizations that want to do them responsibly, which is why the primary two mechanisms that are used to handle payment infrastructure are various forms of Omission and Abdication: outsourcing this functionality to a third party, designing it out of the system entirely, or using systems like cryptocurrency that limit the platform's capacity to manage payments responsibly. This site tries instead to focus on mechanisms for changing the design of features on-platform, which is why these common strategies largely aren't listed."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698735306496,"blocks":[{"id":"D1FKGdjK_c","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Messaging on online platforms refers to the exchange of digital messages between users. This feature can range from private one-on-one conversations to large-scale broadcasting, each requiring different rules and strategies for combatting misuse."}},{"id":"l57mHZfGpJ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Users expect privacy in messaging - as online one-on-one conversations can adopt the closeness and confidence of one-on-one conversations in person. Because of this, many platforms boast end-to-end encryption, which limits a platform's ability to oversee the content of messages. This makes content moderation in messaging particularly challenging. At the same time, users do expect the platform to protect them from universally unwanted forms of abuse like spam, phishing, and malware. User's aversion to content moderation tends not to extend to automated and additive tools like spam filters or warning labels, which help users to sort through or contextualize messages without feeling that their privacy is violated. All of this presents challenges for platforms, because users' expectations of protection and privacy vary, despite the uniformity of the actions from the platform's perspective."}},{"id":"erGvjmXJSA","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Balance between these competing objectives can often be made by leveraging metadata features of conversations to estimate user expectations. Between closely connected individuals in small groups, users expect more privacy. In larger conversations, or conversations with new connections, users expect more protection. One could use this observation about Affinity to gate certain sets of scanning protections or rules. Similar differentiation can be applied via Gatekeeping or Graduated Features."}},{"id":"yTxzIBlfal","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Messaging might seem like a domain where a platform has irreconcilable tradeoffs to make: to implement End-to-End encryption or not, for example. However, when interventions are implemented that tease apart the many contexts in which users message one another, balance can be found."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1699660775759,"blocks":[{"id":"AcxUohJxOj","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Search is such a common paradigm for intentional discovery on the internet, that it is easy to forget that it embodies a variety of design choices which have dramatic effects on the quality of search results, and the capacity the a search has to do (or further) harm."}},{"id":"OcDIkVGRGu","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Both large design principles (like how search results are ordered) and small touches (like how far auto-complete suggests) can have a significant effect both on how users engage with the information that they are looking for, and what information they seek to look for in the first place."}},{"id":"LoRokuRQRr","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Because search is our primary digital mechanism for self-directed exploration, search results have significant (and often competing) burdens:"}},{"id":"JjvCNV7ucQ","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Matching User Intent - searches are at their best when the extend human agency, rather than redirecting the user toward something they weren't looking for.","Preventing SEO - search rankings bring along with them hefty financial rewards, and thus, companies are highly incentivized to find tricks to attempt to game them.","Objectivity - many searches are questions about a shared reality, but can be skewed by the question asked, leading to automated Confirmation Bias.","Non-homogenization - search has the power to heavily centralize the flow of traffic on the internet toward the top few search results - this power can easily be abused, and is challenging to wield responsibly."]}},{"id":"3hENjAePr7","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These competing priorities also have to compete with the search algorithms efforts to attempt to avoid harm."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}
