attributes.Title: Don't support large files
attributes.Definition: Large, high quality, high volume uploads are both risky and expensive.

attributes.Title: Limit Content Reach
attributes.Definition: Put upper bounds on how many people can view/share/interact with content.

attributes.Title: Flatten Virality Curves
attributes.Definition: Cap the attention a user can receive by a multiple of their prior reach.

attributes.Title: Graduated Features
attributes.Definition: Give users access to more powerful features as they engage more deeply.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661677357,"blocks":[{"id":"3l1xqHTS5J","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Graduated Features describes the category of interventions in which access to specific features is gated based on a user's demonstrated responsibility over time. Like a video game where players unlock new levels or tools as they progress, using a gradauated feature approach, newcomers might start with basic capabilitiesposting their own content, or liking other posts, for instance. As users engage positively and abide by community guidelines, they 'level up,' gaining access to more sophisticated tools, such as commenting on other users' posts, sending messages to strangers, or even moderating conversations. This method works because a history of non-problematic behavior serves as a de-facto gauge of trustworthiness. It's an online reflection of the simple societal norm that trust is earned through consistent, respectful actions."}},{"id":"zOCe2bD1YO","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Additionally, explaining this approach to users is straightforward because it mirrors real-life experiences where privileges come with proven reliability. Moreover, by framing features as rewards for positive community interaction, users are motivated to uphold the platform's standards in order to advance toward those capabilities. "}},{"id":"mS6Q__NymU","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Graduated features act as a protective buffer, significantly reducing the risk of various abuses, including spamming, the intentional distribution of misinformation, or other forms of automated inauthentic behavior, since the creation of accounts with a reputation of legitimate engagement can prove a prohibitive barrier. This approach not only fosters a better environment for all users through reducing harm, but when done well, can instill a sense of communal achievement and individual responsibility that enhance the platform as a whole."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: No Comments for Fresh Accounts
attributes.Definition: Don't accept comments from newly created or barely used accounts.

attributes.Title: Right-size content visibility
attributes.Definition: Place limits on the amount of harm content can cause on a platform by restricting its reach.

attributes.Title: Anonymous Limitations
attributes.Definition: Require users to create an account before they can use features that create data or interact with others.

attributes.Title: Delete Abandoned Accounts
attributes.Definition: Prevent high-value usernames from being squatted on by periodically cleaning up inactive accounts.

attributes.Title: Abdication
attributes.Definition: Designing a product feature so that it cannot be moderated.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698133711553,"blocks":[{"id":"nLjzK7VDhq","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Abdication means the intentional design of a product feature in a way that ties a platform's hands on how it can moderate it - the platform Abdicates the majority of its capacity to do integrity work. The most common example of this feature is end-to-end encryption, which prevents platforms from having any visibility into the contents of the encrypted messages that they pass. While End-to-end encryption certainly has benefits for every user's privacy, and is enormously important for free expression within authoritarian regimes, it comes with the downside that platforms have no visibility into the content of messages, and thus cannot prevent the harm that those messages may cause. While end-to-end encryption is the clearest and most extreme example of abdication, there are other examples, like the use of blockchains for storage meaning that content can never be taken down."}},{"id":"40eWCTJ0qH","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Abdication stands apart from the other categories of preventing harm - it isn't a strategy for a platform to prevent harm, it's a strategy a platform employs to try to evade blame for the harm that it causes. While platforms that abdicate their content-moderation responsibilities may claim that they are powerless to act to prevent harmful content from circulating on their platforms, this is disingenuous. Instead, the platform simply made the earlier choice to abdicate this responsibility, and in doing so pre-baked in the ethical tradeoff they find acceptable. Platforms that abdicate responsibility understand (if not encourage) the creation and distribution of some harms (most notably, CSAM), while leaving the platform safer from some other forms of harm (most notably, limitations on free expression). When platforms abdicate responsibility in this way, we should be clear-eyed about, and hold them accountable for, the implications of the tradeoffs that they have chosen to bake into the design of their system."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Escalating Penalty
attributes.Definition: Treat patterns of behavior as more serious than their disaggregated constituent elements.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698134481580,"blocks":[{"id":"iYLcJs7dsK","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"On digital platforms today, \"escalating penalties\" have become a cornerstone of content moderation approaches. This strategy recognizes that not all infractions are created equal, and a pattern of policy-violating behavior warrants more severe repercussions than isolated incidents comprising the same content. Imagine a user making an off-color joke; it might merit a warning, signaling that the content is not appropriate. However, if the behavior continues, the penalties intensify, progressing toward, in extreme cases, permanent exclusion from the platform. This mirrors the way we think about and anticipate punishments and leniency from systems where behavior is evaluated in the real world like schools, governments, and even interpersonal relationships."}},{"id":"N1_L3H0tsI","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This approach, when executed well, can serve as both a deterrent and an educational tool. When users face consequences that intensify with repeated violations, they're given checkpoints at which they are pushed to reassess and adjust their behavior. Pairing these penalties with educational resources is crucial. When a penalty is issued, it should accompanied by information explaining the infraction and providing context on why such content is harmful or unacceptable. This method assumes users' good intent, aiming to guide them back toward acceptable participation norms, rather than punishing them as a form of retribution."}},{"id":"eb0btwoHTG","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Escalating penalties excel in situations where users may be unaware that their behavior is problematic, perhaps because they're new to the platform or unfamiliar with its cultural norms. Once informed, users have the capacity to constrain their behavior, even to norms or ideals that they don't personally accept or hold. However, this system has its limitations, particularly when dealing with highly motivated actors who seek to circumvent or obviate these rules. These individuals often understand the system of leniency within escalating punishments well enough to exploit them, engaging in harmful behavior while avoiding the triggers for more severe penalties. They might also repeatedly test the boundaries of lower-level sanctions, knowing they won't result in significant consequences. Thus, while escalating penalties are part of a robust content moderation framework, they're not a catch-all solution."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Three Strikes: Warn, Suspend, Ban (USA)
attributes.Definition: When users report unwanted sexual advances, use a three strike system.

attributes.Title: Affinity
attributes.Definition: Users' past interactions should shape their future capabilities toward one another.
attributes.Description: {"time":1689085486709,"blocks":[{"id":"ADWKNVO6o9","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A powerful collection of platform intervention falls under the term \"affinity\" - an explicit estimation the level of existing (or potential) connection between two individuals. Though different platforms compute it in different ways, Affinity scores might derive from the users' prior interactions, mutual connections, geographic proximity, and possibly other indicators that signify an existing bond or the potential for one. Today, affinity plays a critical role in countering spam and phishing attacks, but its potential applications extend far beyond that."}},{"id":"QL-kMJJ1DV","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Consider, for instance, a content feed that arranges posts based on affinity, prioritizing content from close connections above all else. Such an arrangement would strengthen social bonds and emphasize the significance of established connections."}},{"id":"AdpDjUZZqu","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Imagine, as another example, a comment system that only permits friends of the post's author to add comments without the author's approval. By implementing this measure, the system designs away the probability of harassment and doxxing."}},{"id":"2nu7XXF5jq","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"At its heart, Affinity is a way to customize a user's experience of an online platform passively, learning from their prior interactions to help build them a space that aligns with their goals.  In a digital world, affinity is an anchor to authenticity, prioritizing digital experiences that honor and amplify the power of human connection."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Affinity To Comment
attributes.Definition: Require a history of interaction between users before they're allowed to interact in comments.

attributes.Title: Request to Follow
attributes.Definition: Make Following a two-sided operation, so that celebs have implicit limits on the ability of fans to follow them.

attributes.Title: Warn before Risky Data Access
attributes.Definition: Use signals about affinity and content to occasionally warn the user about what they're about to see/download/visit.

attributes.Title: Must Request to Message
attributes.Definition: Only allow a user to initiate new conversations with users that they have an established connection with.

attributes.Title: Omission
attributes.Definition: Less is more - a better platform can be achieved by removing pieces of it.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698211509011,"blocks":[{"id":"D3roUoO1nB","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Prevention is often more effective than cure, a principle that when applied to the trust and safety ecosystem brings us the concept of \"feature omission.\" This approach involves intentionally not building (or intentionally removing) features that are likely to amplify or facilitate harmful behavior. Platforms that take this approach can significantly reduce the 'surface area' for potential abuse, thereby restricting the ways in which their services can be used to generate harm. This is particularly important when platforms are honest about their own limitations in understanding all the possible ways that their features are used, and can be misused."}},{"id":"nkhUB1SQa0","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While feature omission might sound like a huge change, it can be used narrowly in combination with other approaches.  Take the challenge of malware. One approach to feature omission would be to prevent users from sharing files with one another, which would certainly prevent malware from becoming a problem! Another approach would be to only allow attachments from users who have messaged back and forth at least three times (an Affinity filter). That would only curtail a small percentage of legitimate usage, while still dramatically reducing the spread of malware on the platform. With the lens of feature omission on, each feature can be divided into a larger number of smaller sub-features. As this process is repeated, the abuse vector tends to cluster into only one or two of the narrowly construed features, and which can then be disabled or discouraged."}},{"id":"nC0v4y8tF5","type":"header","data":{"text":"Why is this a good strategy?","level":2}},{"id":"cpEPwydexa","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In the race for market share, many platforms feel a constant pressure to achieve feature parity with their competitors. However, this race can lead to over-extension, where platforms adopt more features than they can effectively monitor, or even understand user usage. Every new feature can come with unforeseen vulnerabilities or avenues for misuse, particularly if it's rushed to market without adequate understanding or safeguards. The result is often a reactive scramble to address integrity or system-health harms after they've already a problem, rather than a proactive strategy to prevent those harms from occurring."}},{"id":"ZAeoBHCqho","type":"header","data":{"text":"Why Omit?","level":2}},{"id":"iB7AwwBwnR","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A good lens to look at most content moderation efforts through is considering the role that the platform plays in the perpetuation of harm. When the platform offers more robust and powerful functionality, a bad actor can exact more harm for their efforts than they would be able to with a more limited set of functionality. A platform's contribution to harm can be thought of through this lens: how does the platform amplify or enable harm."}},{"id":"o1trrN09Ym","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"With that in mind, the most effective way for a platform to prevent harm is to reduce the potential role it can play in propagating it. "}},{"id":"lxeWIJbCld","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"For instance, platforms that proactively recommend content to users inherently bear a greater responsibility for ensuring that content is safe and non-abusive, since the role they play in the causal chain that leads to harm is of primary consequence. In contrast, subscription aggregation services, which rely on user selection rather than recommendations, have a narrower scope of responsibility. "}},{"id":"F05yShV4ab","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"By deliberately choosing not to implement certain features, platforms can lighten their moderation burden, focusing their efforts on areas they understand well while also diminishing the potential for harm. This strategy of thoughtful feature omission underscores that, sometimes, offering less can indeed provide users with more safety and security."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Omit comment reaction volume
attributes.Definition: Don't prominently display the number of likes or other forms of feedback a comment gets.

attributes.Title: API Surface Area
attributes.Definition: Prevent automated access to features that are intended only for human activity.

attributes.Title: Hide Interaction Counts
attributes.Definition: Foster authentic interaction by making numerical properties less central.

attributes.Title: All Subscriptions Reciprocal
attributes.Definition: Require "following" to be bidirectional to avoid an exponential distribution of reach and attention.

attributes.Title: No E2E Encryption
attributes.Definition: Platforms can offer no content-based protections when content is end-to-end encrypted.

attributes.Title: Don't collect location data
attributes.Definition: Limit storage, retention, and sharing of location information including IP address.

attributes.Title: No Search by Location
attributes.Definition: When abusers can discover content and accounts by location, the creators of content are in danger.

attributes.Title: Use an OAuth Provider
attributes.Definition: Centralize identity management + risk with a company that thinks about it full time.

attributes.Title: Deprioritize User Identity
attributes.Definition: In platforms where the identity of the participants isn't central, omit it.

attributes.Title: Limit Content Reach
attributes.Definition: Put upper bounds on how many people can view/share/interact with content.

attributes.Title: Content Analysis
attributes.Definition: Treating content differently based on its evaluation by automated classifiers.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698127112910,"blocks":[{"id":"nenEDFRrio","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Content Analysis is the pattern of applying policy-defined interventions (like takedowns, de-amplification, or shadow-bans) based on automated analysis of the content.  This is what most folks think of when they think about content moderation efforts, and it tends to take up a significant amount of the time and energies of teams working in Trust and Safety."}},{"id":"KVySp6J2Ub","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though the implementation of a content analysis intervention can vary widely, it typically has the same constituent elements:"}},{"id":"19IcApKZlR","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Automated Identification - using some automated process, find content or behavior that likely violates policy. Identification can be as complex as using a Machine Learning Model, or as simple as looking for exact duplicates of past content.","Intervention - Use a content or account specific tool to minimize the impact of the likely violative content or behavior. This can be as draconian as banning accounts or taking down content, or as subtle as down-ranking violative content.","Appeals - Offer users some way to undo the mitigation through more manual review. These processes tend to be offered because no system of automated identification is right all of the time, and the cost of false positives can be high."]}},{"id":"AO9CbAqF-f","type":"header","data":{"text":"Strengths","level":2}},{"id":"q7o-0pBwkG","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Iterative - Because Content Analysis' detection mechanisms (and intervention approaches) can be trivial or arbitrarily complex, it is easy for companies to stand up a process of content analysis using trivial detections and interventions, and then refine and expand them over time.","Flexible - the process of Content Analysis is easily aligned with the most pressing concerns of a company, allowing a single process and approach to be used across a wide range of harms and challenges.","Necessary - Every platform ends up having to implement some kind of content analysis process for illegal material like Child Sexual Abuse Material, so extending this process to other forms of harm is a straightforward extension."]}},{"id":"lCW5-j9R9v","type":"header","data":{"text":"Weaknesses","level":2}},{"id":"jhBrPiUd_q","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Subjectivity - Content Analysis is explicitly discriminatory between pieces of content, and thus is constantly buffeted by the winds of controversy and anger. Discrimination between pieces of content is trivially perceived and reframed as discrimination between the beliefs, motivations, and identities of the people making the content.","Errors  - Automated Analysis always has some positive and negative error rates - letting violative content through, and incorrectly punishing non-violative content. The creation of a system of automated analysis necessitates downstream the systems for mitigating the effects of its errors.","Circumvention - Content Analysis suffers from offensive asymmetry: it is typically much easier for a malicious actor to create content that violates policy but fails to trigger detections than it is for a trust and safety team to develop an automated classification that catches all such content","Binary - Most content analysis approaches generate binary outcomes, which leaves content that approaches the threshold (\"borderline content\") unmitigated."]}},{"id":"u7WVQjl2lx","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though content analysis is widespread, and likely to be required in some form, it is often tasked with cleaning up messes that it is underpowered to tackle. If a platform incentivizes and actively promotes vitriol, no amount of content analysis can undo the negative consequences of that design choice. This site is making an intentional and narrow argument: platforms should rely less on Content Analysis, by rethinking and redesigning their platforms to be less capable of, and attuned to, the perpetuation of harm."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Perform basic link vetting
attributes.Definition: Run basic validation on the contents that something links to before showing the link to the user.

attributes.Title: Warn before Risky Data Access
attributes.Definition: Use signals about affinity and content to occasionally warn the user about what they're about to see/download/visit.

attributes.Title: Detect Duplicate Content
attributes.Definition: Duplicate content uploads are a strong signal of abuse.

attributes.Title: Don't allow posting of Location
attributes.Definition: Use content filters to prevent users from posting addresses, latitude/longitude coordinates, or other location data.

attributes.Title: Require unleaked passwords
attributes.Definition: During signup, don't allow users to use a password that has been included in a leaked dataset.

attributes.Title: Label identical content
attributes.Definition: For some types of harm, the same data a strong signal of something being off.

attributes.Title: Three Insult Rule
attributes.Definition: Rather than looking at whether individual pieces of content constitute harassment, consider patterns of behavior.

attributes.Title: Humans Only
attributes.Definition: Actively prevent automated use of a feature.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698132546797,"blocks":[{"id":"cXvVpd_AbB","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"One of the most potent vectors for harm on the internet is the use of automation. Platforms that lack robust defenses can quickly become overrun by inauthentic content, as a single malicious actor with some basic knowledge of coding can quickly create accounts and content at a rate that platforms are powerless to stop. Whether it is spam, malware, self promotion, almost any form of deliberate harm on the internet is exacerbated by the use of automation."}},{"id":"qsJ6s4I8zG","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Beyond ensuring that visitors to a site are humans, or validating human status when creating an account, platforms also have control over the degree of automation that they encourage through the technical interfaces that they expose. Platforms that offer free APIs open themselves up to the possibility of scripting in a way that platforms that don't offer these types of machine readable interfaces do not. More technically, platforms that have guessable content IDs enable scrapers to be more efficient and harder to detect than platforms that have encrypted or well randomized URL patterns."}},{"id":"aNC7ari6vV","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Today, building in processes to prevent automated access is fairly straightforward - tools like ReCaptcha offer industry-standard mechanisms that validate that the user on the other end of a browser connection is a human. While these heuristic and task-based approaches to identifying bots work effectively today, there is growing concern that the rapid progress in AI is going to undermine each approach in turn, since it's becoming harder and harder to find isolated tasks that humans can easily do that machines cannot."}},{"id":"XQayGPXCQf","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In light of this, many more security sensitive applications like banking and cloud service hosting are turning to more robust mechanisms of confirming human identity, like trying to tie a user to a unique real-world identity like using SMS verification, physical letters mailed with confirmation codes, or in the most extreme cases, government ID verification. These approaches are more robust to scaled abuse, but bring along with them serious baggage in the form of high costs and privacy intrusions."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Identity Verification
attributes.Definition: Require users to register for an application with a state issued identity document.

attributes.Title: Recommend content only from identity verified accounts
Limit account volume
attributes.Definition: Reducing the volume of accounts a person can create restricts their capacity to cause harm at scale.

attributes.Title: Ordering
attributes.Definition: Impact and perception hinge on what's seen first.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698135420619,"blocks":[{"id":"arA4yl8duO","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Most Digital platforms organize information and direct attention. In both of these functions, the order in which the information ultimately gets presented to the user has an outsized impact on what the user sees, engages with, absorbs, and thus the harm (or benefit) that the content ultimately causes."}},{"id":"T90AOeeztD","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"One subcategory of ordering approaches can broadly be described as \"downranking\": pushing content that appears to be harmful lower in orderings for search and discovery than it otherwise would appear. While downranking approaches can be a potent force for preventing harm, they suffer from the same weaknesses as other forms of Content Analysis: they require automated process to detect potential violative content, and suffer from the challenges of subjectivity, gamification, and false-positives that any type of content-based feature intervention will entail."}},{"id":"i2UHljSdtC","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Other forms of  content-neutral ordering interventions are also promising, if less frequently deployed today. Some platforms that give users explicit control over the order in which they see content, while others randomize the ordering of content. Each of these kinds of interventions has its own strengths and weaknesses, but the commonality is that ordering is a domain fraught with tradeoffs of harms, and that the mechanism (or mechanisms) used for ordering should be considered a cornerstone of a platform's integrity design."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comment Ordering
attributes.Definition: Set the tone for the conversation by choosing the order in which voices are heard.

attributes.Title: User-Defined Subscription Sorting
attributes.Definition: Enable users multiple different options for how to prioritize and filter content from their subscriptions.

attributes.Title: Gatekeeping
attributes.Definition: Limiting participation based on user history.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698211660900,"blocks":[{"id":"mc-89RnLbc","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In the real world, while interactions with strangers are typically neutral and occasionally delightful, the negative interactions we have with strangers (despite their rarity) have an outsized impact on our feelings of safety and belonging. Online, as in the physical world, the loud and destructive voices of a small number of users can negatively skew the experience of a digital space, particularly when users have uniform access to spaces and means of interaction. "}},{"id":"fN3Qs5LE--","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In the context of online communities, \"gatekeeping\" emerges as a practical and effective strategy for safeguarding individual users and communities of users by limiting the set of folks that users can interact with. This concept, a specific aspect of graduated features, involves setting restrictions on user interactions to create spaces with less possibility for interaction with folks not associated with the space. Gatekeeping imposes boundaries that closely resemble our real-world interactions, where certain engagements require pre-established relationships or permissions."}},{"id":"uCIXCdwrh8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A simple example of gatekeeping is restricting users from commenting on posts unless were a followers of the poster at the time that the content was posted. This simple yet effective rule can drastically reduce instances of online abuse, such as Feedback Bombing or Brigading, which is only possible from accounts outside of one's established network. "}},{"id":"CkAzFedrh0","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Gatekeeping has several advantages : It is straightforward to implement from a technical perspective, and it is easy to communicate to users. By limiting the rapid, often anonymous interactions between strangers online, gatekeeping allows for more organic engagement, akin to how relationships develop in the physical world. It gives individuals and communities the autonomy to shape their interaction spaces and decide who can contribute, significantly reducing unwelcome or harmful content. While it's not a panacea for all forms of online abuse, gatekeeping provides a first line of defense, making online spaces feel more personal, respectful, and, above all, safe."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Don't allow adults to message kids
attributes.Definition: Facilitate a sense of safety for parents + kids by only allowing prior connections to initiate conversations with them.

attributes.Title: Feedback Only From Authoritative Sources
attributes.Definition: Allow users with geographic proximity, purchase history, or other signals of engagement to leave ratings.

attributes.Title: Read Before Re-share
attributes.Definition: Prevent gutteral reshares by adding a waiting period estimated by the length of content.

attributes.Title: Require Physical Validation
attributes.Definition: Before leaving a review, require a photo of the reviewed entity.

attributes.Title: Weight Reviews
attributes.Definition: Use the quality of previous recommendations to weight feedback across users.

attributes.Title: Read before Comment
attributes.Definition: Require users to read the primary content before they leave comments.

attributes.Title: Auto-Generated Content Quiz
attributes.Definition: Encourage users to dig deeper than headlines by validating their knowledge of the subject.

attributes.Title: Speedbump
attributes.Definition: A temporary obstacle created to make undesired behavior less frequent, through difficulty or reconsideration.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699211079492,"blocks":[{"id":"KrYBO373a-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Similar to their namesake on the road, online \"speedbumps\" are intentional disruptions or designed obstacles strategically placed in a user's online journey to create a pause. Their purpose is to redirect attention and break the user's frame of mind. These speedbumps aim to guide users away from impulsive behavior and encourage  decision-making in a less agitated mindset. They can appear as pop-ups, blurs, or mandatory redirects, all intended to interrupt the user's flow and promote more considered actions."}},{"id":"5oSRvy8ZA6","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"For instance, imagine a feature that restricts users from responding to a negative comment ten minutes after the negative comment was posted. This forces the user to reflect on what they want their response to look like and only engage if they still find it important after the waiting period. While this feature may cause temporary frustration, it contributes to a space with fewer conflict brawls and, ultimately, a more positive platform atmosphere."}},{"id":"7Lqr2pi5xZ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This category of intervention is also sometimes called \"Friction\" - a term that invokes the same idea: slowing a user down without redirecting them explicitly. The Integrity Institute has an awesome guide on best practices in the design of friction, which I highly recommend."}},{"id":"d2j-jGAa38","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Although speedbumps are well intentioned and can be effective, their weaknesses prevent them from being usful most of the time. Overuse of speedbumps can lead to user frustration, controversy, and even adaptation where they learn to navigate around the interruptions without genuine reconsideration. This mirrors findings about speedbumps in the real world - when overused they result in more reckless driving, not less. Thus, speedbumps should be used judiciously and only in situations where users are likely to voluntarily alter their behavior if given a moment and a compelling reason to reflect."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comment Tone Check Popup
attributes.Definition: Before posting content containing vulgarities, prompt a user to think twice.

attributes.Title: Auto-Generated Content Quiz
attributes.Definition: Encourage users to dig deeper than headlines by validating their knowledge of the subject.

attributes.Title: Warn before Risky Data Access
attributes.Definition: Use signals about affinity and content to occasionally warn the user about what they're about to see/download/visit.

attributes.Title: Third repost has to manually enter the content
attributes.Definition: Slow the spread of vitality by adding friction on repost/re-share functionality.

attributes.Title: Two-Factor Payment Identification
attributes.Definition: Require one user to specify multiple pieces of information about anothother user to send them a payment.

attributes.Title: Read Before Re-share
attributes.Definition: Prevent gutteral reshares by adding a waiting period estimated by the length of content.

attributes.Title: History
attributes.Definition: Utilizing descriptive data to help users understand content in context.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699221231758,"blocks":[{"id":"N4PQj85Qz5","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Some forms of abuse require platform-level views and metrics to identify. Platforms have access to many metrics on individual pieces of content that regular users have no insight into, as well as evaluations of the standard ranges for those metrics across the full platform. In most cases, platforms seek to keep this information to themselves - disclosing it could risk shedding too much light on platform operations and mechanisms. However, in some cases, platforms should consider sharing these metrics to help contextualize information on the platform."}},{"id":"61DomoxAhX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Interventions that follow this pattern can be broadly described as \"History\" interventions. They help users make sense of content by giving them better insight into the user behind the content, and the pattern that the content fits into."}},{"id":"og5cXaAKTD","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Note: well designed interventions in this space will require significant privacy and security mitigations, and will need to think about how to balance the objectives of user control over their representation + identity + privacy, with objectives of transparency and accuracy."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Media Provenance
attributes.Definition: Record and display media's chain of custody and original source.

attributes.Title: Crowdsourced Metadata
attributes.Definition: Allow users limited access to content metadata, and enable them to highlight this on the posts of other users.

attributes.Title: Save Extensive Metadata
attributes.Definition: Recording extensive metadata about sensitive activity can reduce criminal appeal.

attributes.Title: Label identical content
attributes.Definition: For some types of harm, the same data a strong signal of something being off.

attributes.Title: Flatten Virality Curves
attributes.Definition: Cap the attention a user can receive by a multiple of their prior reach.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698265630576,"blocks":[{"id":"B5ke5n8NXa","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"For platforms that are focused on collaboration, communication, or meant to mirror in-person social networks, virality (an explosion of engagement) typically indicates something going wrong. These \"organic\" platforms are attempting to do a physical process (communicate, collaborate, engage with peers) in a digital space, but there is no real-world equivalent for a huge and sudden increase in engagement of any sort."}},{"id":"2zKfEQ44TE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"With this in mind, organic platforms could consider building in rate limiters that try to dampen virality effects when the occur, rather than amplifying them, as many social networks do today. As some examples:"}},{"id":"mLporSvDfH","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"For example, a platform could disallow comments above some expected threshold. Thereafter, only 2x the number of users could comment on a piece of content as commented on it the day prior. This type of system could be tweaked over time to appropriately reflect users' organic patterns of behavior, and their expectations about platform dynamics."}},{"id":"GxudqfMMeJ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"It's also good to note that a rule like this wouldn't necessarily prevent content from going super-mega-viral. It would instead simply dampen the spread of the content - encouraging a slower growth rate in engagement, and a slower uptake in attention. This \"flattening of the viral curve\" (March 2020, anyone?) has significant advantages for both the platform and the user. For the platform this dynamic is easier to intervene in, and allows platforms to take action on objectionable content before it spreads widely. For users, this dynamic would keep them interested in the health and engagement from their posts - spreading out the attentional focus that engagement metrics drive for a given post over a longer period of time."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Feedback Aggregation

attributes.Title: Media Provenance

attributes.Description: {"time":1699661178924,"blocks":[{"id":"vd8zQpJR1z","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Knowing where media came from is often more important than knowing what the media contains:"}},{"id":"Xd5M-g9BS1","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["In cases like Deep Fakes and Manipulated Media, one of the best signals we have for veracity is the source of media, and where it showed up first. The credibility/plausibility of the initial poster having access to the media is a fabulous analogy for the plausibility of the media itself.","In cases like Child Sexual Abuse Material or Election Misinformation, knowing the original poster of the content can help authorities track the content back to its source. In the case of the former, that can often lead to the rescue children from sexual abuse, in the case of the latter it can lead to the prosecution of people who try to disenfranchise at scale.","In cases like Health Misinformation, giving users easy access to provenance information can help users understand where the information is coming from, and assist them track down sources to try to understand their authenticity."]}},{"id":"CH62orC0n8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platforms can make each of these outcomes more likely by retaining records along the line of a \"chain of custody\" - how did user X end up sharing/posting/sending message Y. This is particularly important in situations where re-shares, screenshots, and other forms of reposting can easily obscure the original author of content. Similarly, platforms could create reverse-content-search tools to empower users to find the first post in which a piece of media appears. "}},{"id":"nlVenbdBS2","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"When platforms offer tools to enable the investigation of provenance, they're empowering users to better discern between truth and fiction, and giving authorities the capacity to assign blame for illegal content, ultimately enabling less harm to occur through their platform."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Three Strikes: Warn, Suspend, Ban (USA)
attributes.Definition: When users report unwanted sexual advances, use a three strike system.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698385429526,"blocks":[{"id":"66DaK-mkv9","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This is the combination of two ideas outlined in the Unwelcome Sexual Advances description: most unwanted sexual advances come from a small number of perpetrators, and community specific norms make the reliable classification between wanted and unwanted incredibly challenging at the margins. For these two reasons, a system of escalating penalties for unwanted sexual advances is likely to be highly effective, because the users in the space can be more in control of constructing and policing the norms they want to set in this particular zone, the harmed party is always aware of the harm, and the serial abusers will quickly get kicked off of the platform."}},{"id":"qgAWhstf6m","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A typical three strike system is:"}},{"id":"sEuLhC6RgO","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Warn - on first violation (or in this case, first report) warn the user that their behavior was found to be objectionable, and help them reset their expectations for the space.","Suspend - after a second violation, send a stronger message and force the user to take a time out.","Ban - on third violation, remove the user's account and their ability to continue to use this as a source of harm."]}},{"id":"cyuTZK_B5O","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This approach can be tempered by some sort of classifier to ensure that the content that was reported was potentially construable as being a sexual advance. While ML is very bad at ascertaining the cultural distinctions between unacceptable and acceptable behavior, it will be much better at the task of determining the outer-boundaries of \"could this be construed as a sexual advance\"."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Messaging

attributes.Title: Unwelcome Sexual Advances

attributes.Title: Escalating Penalty

attributes.Title: Identity Verification
attributes.Definition: Require users to register for an application with a state issued identity document.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698270489811,"blocks":[{"id":"iMKv-mor0h","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The pseudo-anonymity that digital platforms offer is typically the core reason that they are used by nefarious actors for intentionally harmful or illegal activity. The physical distance and opacity of identity that the internet offers is a temping shield for those that wish to do harm without being held to account for it. For this reason, concrete identity verification (often through some kind of vetting of a state issued document), has the power to dramatically curtail the appeal of digital platforms for deliberative use in illegal or explicitly harmful activity. Though this frames the intervention as a mechanism to create explicit accountability, this intervention, can also be viewed as an intervention to prevent automation, because identity verification makes it dramatically easier to enforce constraints of one person, one account."}},{"id":"FhANmJlwS7","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though powerful in providing a potential source of accountability, identity verification also has a significant chilling effect on speech and the capacity for it to be heard. Political dissidents, investigative journalists, and members of marginalized populations may have good reason to try to avoid the consequences of their online activities. Children may benefit from accessing the internet without the threat of disclosure to their parents. Anonymity plays a critical role in the facilitation of some of the best parts of the internet - see the Identity feature."}},{"id":"zsT6HD2eZA","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The most pervasive approach to balance these competing objectives is to try to gate powerful features that have significant capacity to cause harm behind identity verification, without requiring it for all users. A media platform might want to require that users verify their identity before they gain access to live-streaming or monetization features, while allowing other features of their platform to be used by unverified accounts. A dating site might hold some power-user features (like messaging non-matches) contingent upon the user verifying their identity."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Require Physical Validation
attributes.Definition: Before leaving a review, require a photo of the reviewed entity.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698214251549,"blocks":[{"id":"B6cJrbQ4vI","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Review bombing, and review boosting are situations where a user leaves feedback on an online entity without consuming the service or product that the review is for. In many instances, this could be dramatically ameliorated if users were required to provide some level of physical validation of their consumption of the service. For example, for restaurant reviews, a user might have to have a location history indicating that they were proximate to the restaurant. For product reviews the user might have to attach a photo of the entity that they are reviewing. This additional data would make for easy fodder for good content-analysis tools: restaurants with lots of reviews non-proximate to it, or products with lots of reviews of things that have minimal or no similarity would be more easily flagged as likely inauthentic."}},{"id":"bBJYpmc13Q","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This approach has significant downsides, however, in that the privacy tradeoffs are stark, and would make implementing a system like this in certain contexts (like rating medical professionals) untenable. Though it cannot be used in every feedback aggregation context, this approach can and should be considered in some."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Feedback Aggregation
attributes.Definition: Collecting user feedback, and condensing it into quantitative scores.

attributes.Title: Periodic Preference Reset
attributes.Definition: Regularly reset the profile used to generate recommendations for a user.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698268763819,"blocks":[{"id":"frQ9wQrjn-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Recommendation systems (and ranking algorithms within subscription aggregation systems) have an unfortunate quirk - they can suffer from their own success, and become too good at guessing what the user will find engaging. In this optimization cul-de-sac, users are left stuck in a rut and highly siloed from other users and other people. Platforms risk the user disengaging broadly from the ecosystem, and users risk hardening their preferences and losing their appreciation for novelty and challenge."}},{"id":"gAR_poHltG","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"One way to counteract this would be to have an option constantly available to users to reset the data that platforms use to recommend them information (but ideally, not lose other pieces of their profile like personal connections, their own posts, etc). This kind of recommendation reset would offer the user the opportunity to explicitly decide to reset their relationship with the platform's recommendation system. That desire could be motivated by a wide variety of self-perceptions on a user's part - like feeling addicted to it, bored by it, or the not feeling like the recommendations actually matched their preferences."}},{"id":"vx7FUCnqGO","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In addition to putting more control into the user's hands, this kind of regulation would go a long way to address privacy concerns - the likes you made in your teens shouldn't be a part of your recommendation profile in your thirties."}},{"id":"kBiOri9Tr7","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Unlike many of the interventions on this site, which only really work as voluntary platform driven changes, this flavor of intervention is a perfect candidate for regulation, which could be framed in a couple of different ways:"}},{"id":"eW4rncbjtb","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Platforms could be required to offer this option to users, maybe including a requirement for a scheduled/periodic reset.","Platforms could be required to ask users if they're interested in this option from time to time.","Platforms could be required to automatically perform this kind of reset once every year or two."]}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698269360944,"blocks":[{"id":"QetPhRdPx0","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"It turns out allowing anyone on the internet to message anyone else on the internet can lead to unintended negative consequences. Who would have guessed?!"}},{"id":"RKEXsiwdbi","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"To cope with this, many platforms have leaned into a category of interventions roughly described as \"consent for messages from unknown senders\" - a type of that segregates messages into a construct like a spam folder based on their implicit likelihood of being desired by the user, using affinity checks, user reputation, and other platform specific signals to inform message routing."}},{"id":"88fI9yOazP","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"At the extreme end, platforms can opt to only allow connected users to message one another - LinkedIn does something like this today, though you can bypass this protection by paying for premium access."}},{"id":"emjKCIG2yL","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This approach can only be employed in contexts where direct messages between strangers isn't explicitly part of the platform's mission. Omegle should not try this approach. Even so, in perhaps the most open-world platform out there, email clients have found this approach workable (spam folder) when used in combination with other heuristics for identifying the likelihood that a user wants to receive a given message."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Right-size content visibility
attributes.Definition: Place limits on the amount of harm content can cause on a platform by restricting its reach.
attributes.Description: {"time":1689466929427,"blocks":[{"id":"0aiLgVrbLP","type":"header","data":{"text":"For content based harms, access volume matters","level":2}},{"id":"g6a7d5xPMl","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"For most content based harms, the magnitude of harm typically stems not from the content itself, but scales with the volume of people that access the content, since the thing that causes harm is the person consuming the content, rather than the content simply existing. As an example, the financial harm that accrues to copyright holders is approximately linear with then number of people that gain access to the content illegally - this is the number of potential customers the IP holder has missed out on. This type of thinking can be applied to a wide range of (but not all) content based harms, including such diverse harms as copyright, malware, violent extremism, deepfakes, and health misinformation. "}},{"id":"Ab9StNctq7","type":"header","data":{"text":"Content sharing features exist along a spectrum of visibility","level":2}},{"id":"1QL2hxxTAT","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platforms provide users the capacity to share content with one another, but do so under different paradigms of content sharing which fall along a spectrum of visibility."}},{"id":"JeaX1W4dff","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Storage only - content is only accessible to the user that created/uploaded it.","1:1 Sharing - content can be shared with individual other users.","1:Many sharing - content can be shared with groups of users, or shared with many users easily.","Public - content can be published such that anyone has the capacity to see it.","Public + Searchable - content is public, and can be easily found by a user that doesn't yet know that it exists.","Recommended - content is not only public, the platform recommends it to users, leading users to see the content even without their intent to do so."]}},{"id":"UcqLUPvk2-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Since a platform deciding which of these modalities of feature sharing they want to support is a design choice, tweaking which of these features are enabled is a way to dramatically reduce the potential for harm on a platform."}},{"id":"u6-OQOo0lF","type":"header","data":{"text":"Align visibility features to trust","level":2}},{"id":"cFhHK2Xz27","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This leads us to a general principle of the design of content-sharing systems: Place limits on the visibility of a user's content aligned with their level of trust."}},{"id":"WB7b2DPSus","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This provides a flexible way of thinking about product restrictions that limits the capacity for users to use platforms to generate harm, with a simple mad-lib formulation: \"only allow visibility feature when a user has signal of trust\"."}},{"id":"j0g14MNoWA","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":" As some examples of how this could be manifested as product rules/features:"}},{"id":"17FXA49Aht","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Require users to be logged in to upload content. (This is particularly important for CSAM, as an example)","Don't allow new users to share content with other users unless they have a prior connection.","Restrict the size of groups that users can share content into.","Don't allow a user to post more than 1000 public items.","Only enable a user's content to be searchable if their account has existed for at least a year.","Only recommend content that comes from accounts that have been ID verified."]}},{"id":"jkosNHDhCR","type":"header","data":{"text":"And... maybe don't?","level":2}},{"id":"bZz-MZ0SIe","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While we often can responsibly use trust signals to restrict visibility features, sometimes there is legitimate question as to whether or not a platform should even support a given visibility level:"}},{"id":"LgwLnBpJjQ","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Should an end-to-end encrypted discussion platform EVER recommend channels to its users? Probably not. ","Should a porn site ever allow an anonymous user to upload videos? Probably not.","Should content from anonymous users ever be recommended? Probably not."]}},{"id":"xbmrMOnXYP","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"As always, the most surefire way to mitigate harm is to think carefully about what the bounds of expected and acceptable behavior should be for an application, and to expressly constrain users' on-platform behavior to what is expected."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Weight Reviews
attributes.Definition: Use the quality of previous recommendations to weight feedback across users.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698217601588,"blocks":[{"id":"83DAnG9Z6a","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In content aggregation systems, the goal is typically to generate numerical scores to estimate aggregate preferences from human feedback. However, ratings from different users are likely to have different levels of value for this task. In the context of location based rating:"}},{"id":"5huVWXQmJ7","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":" A person that visits every pizza place in New York searching for the best slice likely has better discernment on the rating of an NYC pizza joint than the tourist who visits the Sabaro in Times Square. "}},{"id":"vl0Lj3i4BZ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Additionally, The user that leaves all 5-star or all 1-star reviews probably is a less discerning reviewer than the one who leaves a variety of ratings. "}},{"id":"r8DYHGJzUz","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Finally, the rating from a user that has only rated a few things is more likely to be an inauthentic review. "}},{"id":"aiCbFO0m6B","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Implicit in the structured data of a user's ratings over time is a pattern of data in which the usefulness of their recommendations for others can be reasonably well estimated. Averaging these ratings by a series of weights based on past reviews could yield better aggregate ratings, and make the system less susceptible to manipulation by motivated actors."}},{"id":"xJaXYFR_TT","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Though the intervention sketched out here is focused on the goal of accuracy in rating for an average, and thus would have a significant homogenizing effect, that goal is maleable, and the point of differential value for reviews still applies. Ratings could instead be weighted by their similarity to the characteristics a user has expressed an implicit or explicit interest in. A user who consistently leaves comments about the quality of the mobility accommodation in a space might be better served by rating aggregations that weight ratings that mention mobility features highly."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698271166022,"blocks":[{"id":"aLQ_P_TxyD","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This idea is common sense: in systems that try to provide space for public deliberation (like comments) or crowdsourced data (like restaurant reviews), participation can be limited to the parties known to have useful information to share, without losing the value of the system as a whole. Some examples:"}},{"id":"TO3YdNJkqY","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["An eCommerce site could only allow users who have purchased the product through the platform to rate the product.","A movie review site could require a user to take a photo of their ticket stub in order to rate the film while it is still in theatres.","A restaurant review site could require the user's geo-location match the city as the restaurant they are leaving a review for.","A company workplace review site could require the user to verify they have access to an email address with @companyname.com in it.","A neighborhood forum could mail users letters to validate that they live in the neighborhood they claim to before allowing them to post."]}},{"id":"eav1yNpgMb","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This list is far from extensive, and it largely draws on strategies that platforms already use today. Extending this idea to any domain is as straightforward as asking \"how can we tell (with reasonable confidence) that a user is in our target audience\", a question that marketers have a wide swathe of approaches for answering."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698311785535,"blocks":[{"id":"gOV6vfGnLK","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Since comments are an inherently secondary category of content (in response or conversation with a primary piece of content), it would be reasonable for platforms to give the owner of the primary content more controls and capacity to direct the tone and conversation in the comments, as a space for which they have some ownership stake. Platforms could offer post authors controls over their comment sections like:"}},{"id":"wJ9B5dqqYf","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["the ability to delete comments","the capacity to ban accounts from commenting on a post, or commenting on any of the author's posts","the ability to suggest changes","the ability to pre-approve comments before they become visible publicly"]}},{"id":"P95AdeIgH_","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"What makes sense would vary from platform to platform, and it would be critical to also make public and transparent what mechanisms a content author has over their comments, and what actions they have chosen to take on a given post."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1698382767383,"blocks":[{"id":"2gndlZDbTV","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In most cases when users report malicious content or behavior to platforms, a human review evaluates the veracity of the report, and decides on next steps. However in issues of Location Misuse, this is not particularly useful, because the highly contextual nature of location data means that a typical reviewer often can't discern the validity of a location takedown based on the content itself. This, in tandem with the imminent harm that can come from physical location sharing, suggests that a different approach might be useful."}},{"id":"-QqORCB7Bm","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Use well established patterns to discern what constitutes a geo-location: latitude longitude pairs, an address, a postal identifier, ex.","Allow users to report geo-location data specifically, not a full post, as location misuse.","Immediately remove the location from the content, without further review.","Have caps in place to prevent this from being misused. For example, a platform could only allow a user to censor three distinct locations on their platform."]}},{"id":"EhwffXYfss","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This kind of feature would make harms where location data is posted as a threat (Doxxing) significantly less likely."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.RelationshipDescription: Sensitive data should have different thresholds for takedown. Allowing users narrow censorship can minimize the efficacy of doxxing, and dissuade users from doing it.

attributes.Title: Save Extensive Metadata
attributes.Definition: Recording extensive metadata about sensitive activity can reduce criminal appeal.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698389751500,"blocks":[{"id":"VQosHib_g8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Safeguarding platforms from illicit activities often relies on the implicit threat of making it easier for authorities to unmask the user behind the activity. One simple step that platforms can take for that purpose is to extensively record (and consistently persist) metadata around sensitive transactions, like requests to transfer funds, or file uploads."}},{"id":"cYxYXUQSKJ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This can be effective because while certain data points, such as IP addresses, can be conveniently masked through VPNs, many others, like IMEI numbers, prove more challenging for the average user to conceal or spoof. Even seemingly insignificant and trivial to edit metadata (like browser agent) might be useless on its own, but collectively these individual points can form a mosaic that can often identify a person, and even more often can identify a pattern. Even the most advanced actors have a hard time maintaining perfect operational security. Retaining metadata from sensitive transactions keeps alive the possibility of identifying the pseudonymous actor, and the likelihood of being able to identify patterns of abuse after they've occurred. "}},{"id":"4et6NnNexS","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This method is particularly valuable in scenarios like money laundering, where obfuscatory practices are employed to cloud transaction trails, and in the realm of CSAM (Child Sexual Abuse Material), where the meticulous extraction of metadata can often lead investigators to breakthroughs in otherwise inscrutable cases. The mere awareness that such a robust tracking mechanism is in place can act as a powerful deterrent for potential offenders."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Self-imposed time limits
attributes.Definition: Allow users to set hard cutoffs on platform use.
attributes.Description:
{"time":1698738662949,"blocks":[{"id":"QiRSOayOY4","type":"header","data":{"text":"Something is wrong","level":2}},{"id":"WULvuWBtRG","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"The loudest signal that tells me that something is broken in social media is the number of acquaintances, friends, and family, that have expressed this thought: \"I spend too much time on social media, and I am troubled by how little control I have over it.\""}},{"id":"PZFBg8pviJ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"That this sentiment is common tells us that it is time that we start to think about how we can build systems that better enable users to regain a sense of control in their relationship with social media (or digital platforms writ-large, including gaming, shopping, streaming, etc). Empowering users needs to center around that all-too-common concern: time."}},{"id":"3px4E-F31t","type":"header","data":{"text":"Half way there","level":2}},{"id":"OMWt-T8oQd","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This problem has been partially answered by existing systems. A number of applications and operating systems now have features that remind users about the amount of time they spend on platform, and some have even offered \"speed-bump\" type features that interrupt the user after a user-defined timer has run out. "}},{"id":"FIbVwyVsPE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This is only half of the puzzle, however, because the efficacy of this kind of \"report and interrupt\" strategy relies on the user to be able to overcome the urge to dismiss it, or make the few taps to subvert or change the rule itself. Interruptions and timers attempt to engage our brains in long-term, planning type thinking, at a time when the problem is the state of mind that the platform induces: a more short-term, reward based thinking. The fact that timers and reminders are ineffective is one of the reasons that attention-hungry platforms have been willing to build them into their apps."}},{"id":"9tkedGp0LV","type":"header","data":{"text":"Allow users to set predefined limits","level":2}},{"id":"4TwkxEgDST","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"What we need instead is the capacity for individuals to set hard activity and app timers, which would prevent the user from any further use of the application until the time renewed/cooled off. You could imagine these being built in a number of ways:"}},{"id":"ymDGK5NDLP","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["An app could allow a user to set a total time limit for the day or week, and stop working in any way after that time.","An app could allow a user to set a access time and cooldown time, such that the user can access the app for the access time, and then cannot access it until the cooldown time has elapsed.
","An app could allow users to set time-of-day restrictions on their usage, preventing use in the time before bed, for example.
","An app could allow a user to set any of the above types of limits for specific functionality within an app - for example, allowing them to continue to interact with messaging features while setting hard timers on recommended content feeds.","An operating system could enable these features cross-app, expanding their reach and efficacy."]}},{"id":"c6jY19ihq9","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Any one of these changes would be a step-change from today's capabilities, where many users turn to third-party apps that are only mostly effective in performing this kind of self-limitation."}},{"id":"5pVfFdYRGo","type":"header","data":{"text":"An analogy","level":2}},{"id":"m3fJRpUaqX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Casinos are designed for addiction - the thrill of chance, the rush of winning, and every element of casino design are engineered to tickle the brain of the casino-goer into spending more time (and losing more money) in the place. Knowing this, one might suggest that people ought exercise willpower, and never enter this space, since it is designed for addiction."}},{"id":"1IhBiafZuL","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"That advice isn't particularly useful for people who want to experience some of the pleasures of gambling, but avoid the slippery downfall. Instead, the typical advice is to select an amount of money that the gambler would feel OK about losing, and only bring that amount of money to the casino, in cash - leaving the debit/credit cards at home."}},{"id":"8dlF15IRAc","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A pre-defined, strictly enforced time limit is the equivalent of this feature - setting a limitation while you're not under the influence of the addictive space, and in doing so, enabling yourself to enjoy the addictive space within the freedom of restriction. "}},{"id":"N9m9RLq7xx","type":"header","data":{"text":"A fantastic target for regulation","level":2}},{"id":"a2GGLyP7sK","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"I find this to be a compelling target for regulation because "}},{"id":"rqq4KNxUvD","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["It is straightforward to define in legally precise terms","It vests control with the end user","It ameliorates the user concern about a lack of control without demanding abstinence.","It is content and platform agnostic - these kinds of restrictions would be easy to build + standardize across products."]}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Delete Abandoned Accounts
attributes.Definition: Prevent high-value usernames from being squatted on by periodically cleaning up inactive accounts.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699220004731,"blocks":[{"id":"tikAsT2Mbs","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Abandoned accounts pose a number of risks (optical, regulatory, and abusive) for platforms:"}},{"id":"EossmJoiHd","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["They are easier targets for account hijacking.","They reduce a platform's engagement statistics.","They are an active cost center - storage isn't free.","They are privacy risks (under GDPR)","They prevent users from utilizing the squatted resources they consume."]}},{"id":"9hMf_XmzMC","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Cleaning up inactive accounts (deleting their data, and then freeing up the resources they consume, like usernames) is a good piece of hygiene that helps platforms mitigate long term risks like the above, but has to be done carefully to minimize risks of impersonation."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Identity
attributes.Definition: Individuals' ability to represent themselves in a digital space.

attributes.Title: Squatting
attributes.Definition: Collecting high value usernames for resale, ransom or confusion, rather than for use.

attributes.Title: Graduated Features
attributes.Definition: Give users access to more powerful features as they engage more deeply.

attributes.Title: Limit account volume
attributes.Definition: Reducing the volume of accounts a person can create restricts their capacity to cause harm at scale.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699220736003,"blocks":[{"id":"mgwaJmAujp","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Since almost all forms of intervention operate on a logged-in user, a common strategy for scaled abuse is the creation of many accounts, either managed by a single user switching between contexts, or using automated tools. Before getting too much into this, it's important to note that there are some legitimate cases where a user would want (or need) access to multiple accounts. Politicians, kids followed by their parents, LGBTQ youth in unsupportive situations, people who do social media as a job, in each case, the person's ability intentionally cultivate their identity requires the use of distinct personae. Platforms tend to understand and support this need, but their support drops off quickly - most platforms are fine with users having two accounts - most don't want users to have more than ten."}},{"id":"YBmrGu_Tjv","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Today, platforms that want to enforce their limits on account creation tightly do so through SMS verification, in combination with limiting the number of accounts that can be tied to a given phone number - they might allow a user to use the same phone number for two or three accounts, but block the creation of the fourth account with the same phone number. "}},{"id":"yEIyl8pXzx","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platforms that are less concerned about the problem, but still don't want automated access to their systems, often gate the creation of an account on the solving of a captcha."}},{"id":"6c3uLVPn6N","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Just like everything, there isn't a \"right\" answer here. A platform should set up explicit expectations of how many accounts they expect a user to have in the most permissive use cases, and then find technical ways of enforcing that boundary. This is essential to get right before a platform scales, since intervention at the account creation stage is infinitely easier than trying to unwind a complex network of personae after they've been created and used."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Temporal Comment Limits
attributes.Definition: Restricting the volume of comments people can post will make folks think twice about their actions.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698267564845,"blocks":[{"id":"tALO0yrBMQ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A vanishingly small number of users generate the overwhelming majority of negative online comments. For that reason alone, platforms should place a variety of bounds on the volume of comments that individual users can generate, and could do so along a variety of overlapping and intersecting dimensions. These limitations could be absurdly high and still have significant positive impact, because the users at the 99th percentile of comment volume are consuming dramatically more than 1% of the communicative space. Some examples:"}},{"id":"WuC7qdeyoP","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Limit the number of comments a user can post in an day to 100.","Limit the number of comments a user can post in an hour to 10.","Limit the number of comments a user can post on content posted by a user that doesn't follow them (a limit paired with an Affinity strategy)"]}},{"id":"6xXqktaTv0","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These limits are just a few potential ways of framing this approach, and they aren't exclusive. The best approach here would be a set of overlapping restrictions, each constraining unexpected user along their specific timescale or dimension, adding up to a robust guardrail for expected user behavior over time."}},{"id":"QgGvTH1wpS","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These kinds of approaches (i.e. Limits) work because limits are concrete expressions of a platform's norms. It is very likely that users at the tail ends of a distribution (like the number of comments in a day) are behaving in ways that are antithetical to the norms of how the platform (and other users) expect them to behave."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Bulk Location Takedown Tools
attributes.Definition: Allow a user to scrub their profile of location data while leaving other data intact.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698383396047,"blocks":[{"id":"QU7zGFMOBp","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Threats to users that stem from their Location Data tend to emerge suddenly. A user may post their location data happily for years, and then only after they start to be stalked, find that the digital detritus of their location data has swiftly become a liability."}},{"id":"ldwxQouSzG","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platforms can help users that experience this unfortunate change of circumstance with tooling to quickly remove (or change the visibility of) all of their location data across all of their content. A feature of this sort could be of particular use because often location features of a user's content aren't clearly legible to the user themselves: most people probably don't know that most photos encode timestamps and location data. Additionally, building a feature like this is in a platform's interest: without this tool, a user trapped between retaining their profile and protecting their physical safety is very likely to choose to delete their profile entirely. "}},{"id":"7gUocNk8Ca","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This type of feature would be fairly easy for most platforms to build, but would routinely prove critical to the safety of a small but vulnerable set of their users."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: All Subscriptions Reciprocal
attributes.Definition: Require "following" to be bidirectional to avoid an exponential distribution of reach and attention.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661318828,"blocks":[{"id":"_6CQFpVyHz","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This intervention changes the nature of a subscription based site by unifying two actions \"user A subscribes to user B's posts\" and \"user B subscribes to user A's posts\". This form of limitation is most often expressed through the semantics of \"friend requests\". Another way of framing this requirement is the omission of the feature of one-way subscription."}},{"id":"9Dqe5KLffX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Requiring subscriptions to be reciprocal has a number of advantages to user safety, making it harder for folks to Stalk or Doxx one another. Its larger effect, though, is to preference social relationships (a relationship between two people) over parasocial ones (a relationship between a creator and an audience). Similar to Limit Number of Subscriptions, this approach would make it harder for influencer-dynamics to take hold, and would direct user attention and energy toward their real-world relationships."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1689467488696,"blocks":[{"id":"NBLsV_WKgX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Copyright infringement happens on every site on the internet that enables users to upload and share content. Placing reasonable limits on file upload + sharing can dramatically reduce a site's usefulness for piracy. "}},{"id":"MgkFXdh0sQ","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["Limiting file uploads to 100MB or less reduces a site's usefulness for piracy writ-large.","Limiting uploaded video to 70 minutes reduces usefulness for pirating movies.","Limiting the number of uploads a user can make in a day to 10 or fewer reduces usefulness as a medium for pirating TV shows."]}},{"id":"OYgv02z-J5","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This simple change also has significant benefits for reducing infrastructure cost risks, and if it doesn't impact the business use case, doesn't really have downsides."}},{"id":"8-nXSwmsoj","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"As always, product designers can think about how to provide users that have greater levels of trust the ability to bypass these limitations, as a form of a graduated feature."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}
