attributes.Description: {"time":1699227561982,"blocks":[{"id":"SGNDxDNz3n","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Lots of ink has been spilled saying that the internet (and in particular, twitter) was better back in the good old days of reverse chronological feeds. When Twitter eventually capitulated to this common user request, there was less ink spilled on the results - it seems like the people who really wanted this feature used it happily, most folks never switched to it, and some switched back after realizing it wasn't the panacea they thought it might be."}},{"id":"f-_0RPzdn8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While reverse-chronological gets a ton of love, it's worth thinking about this as a single instance of a larger question: how could users tune the parameters of the algorithms that decide what they see? "}},{"id":"zdXoZQv6VE","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["They could have filtering options at every layer of control","They could have sorting options, and the ability to create aggregated sorting functions of their own weights","They could have the option to subscribe to the tuning parameters of a third party (similar to independently maintained blocklists on twitter prior to twitter becoming X)","They could enable users to choose more consistency or more variation in their recommended content","They could allow users to choose whether their content gets grouped by subject or comes in alternating order, etc."]}},{"id":"vvJc5zMeKE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":" It seems like such a rudimentary idea, but below the surface there are tons of different mechanisms and formulations of this, many of which have been implemented under disparate names across different platforms. The reality of algorithmic recommendation is fractally complex, and not something I'm particularly well equipped to write about. Exposing a user to every lever that every engineer who has ever worked on a recommendatino system would be needless. However, a system that allows users more fine-grained control over the content they see seems worthwhile, allowing people to express with their feet their preferences for the inevitable tradeoffs that these algorithms embed within them. "}},{"id":"kZ7ObcLKSa","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"I expect we will see this emerge in the fetaverse organically, but one could imagine a highly motivated platform using this kind of customization as their differentiator, or a regulation passing that compels this kind of customization."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Description: {"time":1699221402839,"blocks":[{"id":"U3XirpwHro","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This one is a simple egalitarian idea: why should one person's content have more of a reach than another's? "}},{"id":"BR50w9SPv-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A bunch of platforms adopt this strategy implicitly. Omegle and other forms of randomized-chatrooms do this. "}},{"id":"2QD6G_0Kuz","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This has huge upsides and downsides. It's not advisable in most circumstances. It's added here because even oddball ideas deserve listing!"}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Reporting Mechanisms
attributes.Definition: Allow users to flag content or behavior that they find to be abusive.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698220055961,"blocks":[{"id":"y2S_6kfBR8","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Reporting is the historical bedrock of counter-abuse protections on platforms. A Platform's users will almost always know something is wrong before the platform itself has the capacity or time to notice. The deputization of users as reporters in the content moderation process simultaneously empowers users to see themselves as co-creators of the safety of the online spaces that they enhabit, while helping integrity teams optimize how they direct their time and attention toward the issues that users are feeling most acutely."}},{"id":"ogRsbtdbJo","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"However useful reporting is at generating visibility, it is part of a solution, not a full one. Firstly, when backed by human review, the costs of report evaluation, response, and triage grow in proportion with the volume of visible abuse on the platform, so when platforms are inundated with novel forms or strategies of abuse, it is common for reporting functions to become overrun. Moreover, though reporting is useful at getting visibility into acute and legible forms of abuse, it often fails to shine a light on issues that aren't obvious to the user that is harmed by them, like malware, which is hard for the user to detect, or hate speech, which often occurs out of view from the parties harmed by it. Additionally, reporting systems have to be linked to careful review prior to action being taken on content, otherwise they can be trivially used for capricious or ideological attempts to take down the content of opponents. Finally, reporting is always a slow and reactive process, and while it can provide a sense of solvency and action for the reporting user, in reality it doesn't prevent the majority of harm that the content causes."}},{"id":"R3BR7OQuV4","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Because of their ubiquity, many sets of industry best practices have emerged that give excellent advice for how to build and reform reporting practices. Though only part of a broader trust and safety strategy, when reporting systems are built well, they have the capacity to encourage users to feel empowered, safe, and heard, while giving platforms clear visibility into what their users are currently being frustrated by."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: No Comments for Fresh Accounts
attributes.Definition: Don't accept comments from newly created or barely used accounts.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661388532,"blocks":[{"id":"n-kWUggG2n","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"\"Fresh\" accounts are accounts that were either created recently, or don't have much of a history of organic activity. Activity by fresh accounts is a frequent signal of Coordinated Inauthentic Activity, either through automation, troll farms, or just an individual user creating a second account to settle a score. As platforms have iterated on their content moderation strategies, many have found that the overwhelming majority of violating content within some abuse categories (particularly spam) are perpetrated by fresh accounts. This suggests a simple solution: don't grant fresh accounts powerful capabilities until they have a demonstrated track record of constructive, human-like, behavior in less critical domains - the basis of the argument for Graduated Features generally."}},{"id":"Mv78yd9bZt","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Since comments are a common venue for internet turf wars and personal vendettas, they're an ideal candidate for a set of functionality to hold back until users have been interacting on the platform (and not causing problems) for a while."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comments

attributes.Title: API Surface Area
attributes.Definition: Prevent automated access to features that are intended only for human activity.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698737217193,"blocks":[{"id":"DOUBEMx8jt","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) are structured mechanisms for two computer systems to interact with one another. Platforms typically offer APIs in order to assist developers and researchers that build tools for their platforms, or seek to study it. APIs typically offer controls and actions that mimic the set of actions that a user could take on the platform (listing, searching, reading, posting, etc)."}},{"id":"z5-4jdbgol","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"However, Platforms should consider the surface of their API (the set of functionality they enable) carefully. Many actions on a platform are designed and intended only for human use, and enabling API access to create data or mutate state in these features is likely to lead to unwanted automation. Of particular focus should be API mechanisms that allow users to create data in ways that might appear to others as posted by a human. Omitting data creation features like these would not impinge on other uses of the API, like listing, reading, searching, and deleting."}},{"id":"7rAF1noq0k","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Using this approach in combination with other flavors of interventions (like limits and graduated features), API designers can create systems to gate access to powerful capabilities (like the ability to create data data) to users that have exhibited signals of trust, and confined themselves to the limits set out by the API."}},{"id":"TcdHVdj_Yj","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"APIs are powerful tools - platforms should design them with abuse in mind."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comments
attributes.Definition: Expressions of response to either some primary content, or other comments.

attributes.Title: Feedback bombing

attributes.Title: Omission
attributes.Definition: Less is more - a better platform can be achieved by removing pieces of it.

attributes.Title: Anonymous Limitations
attributes.Definition: Require users to create an account before they can use features that create data or interact with others.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698558592153,"blocks":[{"id":"NwbKE0Fd_C","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This intervention is so straightforward that we're used to seeing it (and expect it) on most of the internet already: require people to sign-in in order to take some actions."}},{"id":"KDFWFToOhE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This straightforward approach uses a user's choice to create an account and log in as a mechanism of trust, and rewards that trust with additional functionality. This has several benefits:"}},{"id":"3lV7M8cPde","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Though not impossible, it is much harder to automate actions or scrape content off of a site that requires login.","Account creation creates a checkpoint to ensure the user is a human, after which they can be assumed to be. This is why seeing or completing a ReCaptcha during account-creation is so common.","Account creation is an implicit warning that the account (and thus the access to the features that account creation enabled) can be deleted, and the access to the features withdrawn.","Account creation, and then subsequent correlation of activity by the account leaves a trail of metadata that can be helpful for identifying abuse, and reporting it to law enforcement."]}},{"id":"LCOJ8TX2A3","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Limiting powerful features to logged-in users does not mean not allowing anonymous access. Anonymous access and use can be safe in a variety of contexts. However, the presence of any of these features should generally be behind some kind of authentication barrier:"}},{"id":"Dz8obcYqP-","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["The ability to persist data to the platform","The capability to take actions that can impact what other users see","The functionality to incur nontrivial resource costs."]}},{"id":"oqe8kHbO8h","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These are guidelines, not rules. Well defended systems and well designed systems can sometimes offer narrow instantiations of these functionalities safely."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Auto-Generated Content Quiz
attributes.Definition: Encourage users to dig deeper than headlines by validating their knowledge of the subject.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698737860932,"blocks":[{"id":"nrcDjrWjq6","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"On most platforms, features are enabled by default. Though this paradigm is common, it needn't be the default. Gating access to features based on demonstration of some capability has the capacity to select for that capability in the actions that get executed on a platform."}},{"id":"RkF-svjuYF","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"As one example, imagine a re-share button on a social media post that started off greyed out. If the user clicks it, they learn that they first have to read the article, and only then can they re-share the content. The user clicks on the link, and visits the article page. When returning to the platform, if the user presses the re-share button again, they're prompted with a 2-3 question multiple-choice quiz about the content they just read. It could be generated through any number of AI tools in rapidly accelerating use today. If the user gets the question right, the post editor pops up and they can re-share, otherwise they're encouraged go back to the article and guess again."}},{"id":"k9LP7U2wWW","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This would be annoying for users habituated to the current model for re-sharing content. However, a platform designed from scratch with this kind of \"real information ethos\" baked into it might be more successful, both at encouraging re-shares (as a more merit based signal of knowledge) and likely at limiting the spread of misinformation."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Read before Comment
attributes.Definition: Require users to read the primary content before they leave comments.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698738136996,"blocks":[{"id":"SM2wiAzgRB","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Comments often reflect the perspective and opinions of people that have not engaged with the content deeply. Instead, comment Sections often serve as a performative space where group identity can be expressed and constructed and interpersonal connection can be affirmed and displayed. While that might suit the needs of platforms that are built for  this kind of identity building, other platforms that wish to prioritize space for conversation on the merits of content might need a different approach."}},{"id":"nePsh6cux-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A platform could gate the ability to post a comment based on the passage of time, as a way to estimate whether a user has actually read the content.  For example, on a video this could be the duration of the video, or on a text post it could be scroll depth or time off site. To implement this on an existing site might be too large of a behavioral change to ask users to make, but new sites ought consider this form of gatekeeping when they endeavor to prioritize space for informed discussion."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Limited Number of Subscriptions
attributes.Definition: By limiting the number of subscribers (or the number of subscriptions), a platform can design toward real-world connections, and away from exponential scale distributions.
attributes.Description: {"time":1698740567655,"blocks":[{"id":"qNByXJQPqY","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Subscription systems are sometimes designed to be used for broadcast to facilitate one to many communication, for example, podcast feeds. Other subscription systems are intended for use in forming and strengthening interpersonal connections (ex: friend connections, dating apps, etc)."}},{"id":"UomrjTqpCZ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":" Platforms aiming for this second category could consider limiting the volume of connections a user can build up. A dating app could limit you to having only five matches at a time. A social media app could limit you to having only 10,000 friends. In both instances, the platform would use the design of the platform's limitations to express expectations of use, while curtailing the platform's use for other purposes. On such a dating site, aspiring influencers couldn't use the approach to farm followers. On such a social media site, influencers couldn't exist, since the relatively low cap on connections would prevent unbounded growth in the attention they could garner."}},{"id":"zrm0ApCC3G","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While these kind of limitations aren't for every platform, they're an important reminder that the patterns of behaviors that arise on digital platforms are constructs of their design, rather than the organic features of the people that congregate to them."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Read Before Re-share
attributes.Definition: Prevent gutteral reshares by adding a waiting period estimated by the length of content.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699210861880,"blocks":[{"id":"ndakJ4ulqX","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Content often spreads on social media without people engaging with it deeply, often as part of a performative signal about and crafting of group identity.  Platforms that wish to subvert this dynamic might gate the ability to re-share content based on some kind of speed bump to estimate whether a user has actually read the content - either as an input to a recommendation algorithm that decides the importance of the content to other users, or in the most extreme case, preventing a re-share of content before this time period has elapsed, since that time period is easy to set a reasonable confidence window on. For example, on a video this could be the duration of the video. On a multi-image social post it could be only once you are at the end. On a text post it could be scroll depth or time off site."}},{"id":"g13f0JBZtu","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This kind of intervention (since it would add a huge amount of friction in an existing platform) would probably only be advisable in a new platform. In general, interventions that add friction are (a) harder to add after a platform has ossified into its norms of usage, and (b) require more user buy-in."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comment Ordering
attributes.Definition: Set the tone for the conversation by choosing the order in which voices are heard.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699212913452,"blocks":[{"id":"dRZoGcTaGC","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While no form of comment ordering is \"right\", each form will optimize for certain behaviors, and against others. Platforms that are trying to build for a specific use case, or engender particular user norms, are well served by considering which methodology best suits their goals."}},{"id":"F5J4qtB34n","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Likes Descending encourages response to the primary content over discussion within the comments. It will encourage dunking, but make for some entertaining content.","Chronological encourages users to post their reactions quickly, and allows the fastest voices to have an outsized impact, both on the perception of the original content, but also on the tenor of the contents that follow.","Reverse Chronological highlights newer perspectives and ideas, rotating them in as new ones occur. This would encourage people to post multiple times, and minimize the attention any one comment or commenter could get.","Number of Sub-comments in a nested comment system can be a way of guaging where the discourse (good and bad) is at. This prioritizes discussion, but also encourages outrage bait.","Randomized would be another way of doing comments that seems to be highly neutral. However, users might be encouraged in this model to post more often, so as to have a higher probability of being toward the top of a comment section.","Least Controversial While Positive is possible in capture signals of positive and negative sentiment (when reaction is split, that's controversy). This is the option I've heard proposed that I like the most, but even it has flaws.","Offering users choice over comment ordering algorithms could add another layer on top of this issue."]}},{"id":"l5xrdEDpz9","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These are just a few ideas - there are a thousand other ways that comments could be implemented, and each carries with it these kind of tradeoffs. In software design there aren't right or wrong answers, just a lot of ways to trade off between competing aims."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Definition: When abusers can discover content and accounts by location, the creators of content are in danger.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699226060570,"blocks":[{"id":"DALQQkYePJ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Unless the purpose of your app is physically finding out who is nearby, you probably don't want it to be used that way. Stalking, harassment, and general creepiness are all facilitated by search-by-location features."}},{"id":"o3HpnI2Dbn","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"When search-by-location is necessary, it can typically be approximate, with common tools like giving approximate locations, search radii, fuzzing (adding random noise to location data), or minimizing the granularity of the location query you can request."}},{"id":"0kjD9Hkczn","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":" Granularity in this context should consider the volume of the response set, not the size of the area - a five mile radius might not be enough in Wyoming, and might be too much in New York."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Search
attributes.Definition: Locating and ranking content to be responsive to a user's query.

attributes.Title: Location Misuse
attributes.Definition: Malicious use of geo-location data to stalk, harass, or harm.

attributes.Title: Stalking
attributes.Definition: Persistent, unwanted surveillance of an individual, often causing fear and distress.

attributes.Title: Harassment / Cyberbullying
attributes.Definition: Unwanted and repeated behavior that threatens, annoys, or intimidates a victim.

attributes.Title: Unwelcome Sexual Advances
attributes.Definition: When a user initiates a sexual or romantic exchange with another outside of a reasonable context.

attributes.Title: Omission
attributes.Definition: Less is more - a better platform can be achieved by removing pieces of it.

attributes.Title: Affinity To Comment
attributes.Definition: Require a history of interaction between users before they're allowed to interact in comments.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661487986,"blocks":[{"id":"YRv_dmoQHF","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Comments are the site of abuses including harassment, discrimination, and doxxing, where the victim is the author of the primary content, and the abusive user typically has no prior relationship to the victim."}},{"id":"HQfzn-GYwd","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This pattern can be avoided by creating measures of interpersonal affinity and using that to gate access to the ability to leave comments: only a user with some level of affinity to the author of a post would be allowed to comment on the post."}},{"id":"Sj0tNKP_GA","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This could be made more effective by putting this power in users' hands, offering them the ability to control comments on their posts at a granular, and per post, level. An example set of controls could allow commenters to be (a) anyone online (b) logged in users (c) two degrees of affinity (d) direct affinity, or (e) only specific people."}},{"id":"FVjk2GiDum","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Putting power in users' hands tends to be a winning strategy for harms where they're directly effected by the harm when it occurs, as these forms of comment-abuse do."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Comments
attributes.Definition: Expressions of response to either some primary content, or other comments.

attributes.RelationshipDescription: Spam requires the constant fabrication of new accounts with few real connections to other users, so affinity checks are significant checks on spam.

attributes.Title: Use an OAuth Provider
attributes.Definition: Centralize identity management + risk with a company that thinks about it full time.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661611259,"blocks":[{"id":"jedpMyJxrV","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Authentication is hard to get right - see require unleaked passwords for just a few of the challenges around passwords, and the challenges of verifying who is a human, or preventing multiple account sign ups are challenges that even the largest organizations struggle with."}},{"id":"cpTdBgZlNA","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Platforms are better off (when they're able) outsourcing identity management to an OAuth provider. Centralized providers are better able to filter out robots, to prevent users from creating many accounts, and ensuring the handle the details of user authentication in a way that is cryptographically secure."}},{"id":"ut5EH_Wx4q","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While this comes at some small privacy risk, and hardens your users' reliance on the OAuth service itself, these harms are small relative to the significant improvements in security and human-representation that platforms can gain through the use of a 3rd party provider."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Identity
attributes.Definition: Individuals' ability to represent themselves in a digital space.

attributes.Title: Identity Theft
attributes.Definition: Stealing credentials or other personal information, typically for financial impersonation.

attributes.Title: Crowdsourced Annotations
attributes.Definition: Allow users to add context to the posts of others when it is widely seen to be useful.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699211969625,"blocks":[{"id":"Dztb3rGry4","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While in some cases \"more speech\" can answer inaccurate or harmful speech, by default, the structure of information display on a platform doesn't put \"counter speech\" in direct conversation with the speech that it aims to address."}},{"id":"etVws1mB29","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Some attempts to change this have been made in the realm of crowdsourced annotations - pieces of context that users can attach to primary content, which will appear in the view of any users that see the primary content. This is typically gated behind some kind of twin mechanism of aggregated feedback, only allowing the context to be attached if there is broad consensus about its utility."}},{"id":"3x7yvXkU5u","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"These systems have the potential to be partial antidotes to misinformation on platforms, though they can't solve the thornier varieties of the problem. They're reactive, they can be abused, they take effort for the contributor, and they outsource the determination of accuracy to the consumers of the content, who are unlikely to be objective neutral jurors. Despite these flaws, systems like this are starting to gain traction, and where they work, they offer the best of all worlds: an approach that is content neutral, that scales, and that helps users better sort out truth from fiction."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Search
attributes.Definition: Locating and ranking content to be responsive to a user's query.

attributes.Title: Manipulated Media / Deep Fakes
attributes.Definition: Inauthentic media that passes itself off as authentic.

attributes.Title: Political Misinformation
attributes.Definition: Spreading false or misleading information to influence political attitudes and outcomes.

attributes.Title: User Control
attributes.Definition: Giving users capability controls over a circumscribed perimeter.

attributes.Title: Limit Content Reach
attributes.Definition: Put upper bounds on how many people can view/share/interact with content.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699226640779,"blocks":[{"id":"wuERL7BFnF","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"We often take for granted that the internet has viral dynamics built into it, but that's just one design choice. Rather than actively amplifying content, platforms could create caps on engagement, and optimize for engagement up to that cap, but not beyond it. In a proactive content recommendation feed, this might mean that after recommending content to 10,000 people, the platform wouldn't recommend it to anyone else. "}},{"id":"yf54pWusUu","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Why might a platform take this type of thing on? Since virality is a mechanism the platform uniquely enables, it's role in the causal chain that can lead to harm is fundmentally different in the case of harms that happen through virality when compared with harms that happen through other avenues (consider digital means replacing physical means in blackmail) - in virality harms the contribution of the platform to the harm is larger, and it is in a more unique role to mitigate it. If virality isn't a core goal of the platform, platforms can (and should) consider building in mechanisms to prevent virality from occurring on the platform, since the dynamics that virality introduces are expressly beyond their ambitions, and are likey things they're not equipped to (or thinking about how to) handle well."}},{"id":"271FNiG_7o","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Within this context, the idea of placing limitations on the reach content can achieve through recommendation systems makes sense, but it requires the platforms to have a clear-eyed view of their capacity to cause harm, their responsibility to mitigate it, and the ethical imperative that connects the two. That probably won't happen without strong public pressure, legislation, or both."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Definition: Broadening a user's information diet through deliberate mechanisms of alternative exposure.

attributes.Title: Label identical content
attributes.Definition: For some types of harm, the same data a strong signal of something being off.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661464958,"blocks":[{"id":"IxIkDAaZpB","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Some platform features (\"original features\") are solely intended to facilitate collaboration, communication, or sharing original work. The spontaneous, unrelated creation of duplicate files, messages, or images in an original space is extremely improbable when the media is large enough (>1KB). This means that duplicates can be a leading signal of abuse, since it indicates that users are utilizing the features for purposes other than original creations. "}},{"id":"qypc7L_Cgx","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Some platforms have even gone so far as to prevent the creation of duplicate images or videos, to encourage engagement with the original work on the platform. That approach is probably not suitable for most platforms as a rule, but the approach is likely suitable for most as a leading signal of abuse and a jumping off point for further investigation."}},{"id":"kMbkxl_ep_","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Duplicates can also be tied into strategies for provenance. In original features, it is typically useful for users to know that the content that they are viewing is non-original. Therefore, adding a button indicating non-original content (and linking to its source) would be helpful for users to gain some context about the content by ascertaining its origin."}},{"id":"GioB8aAiGD","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While exact, byte-for-byte duplicate detection systems are trivially easy to circumvent, a wide array of literature and software exists to do duplicate detection today, particularly in the domain of copyright enforcement and CSAM. Repurposing these techniques to deliver features for user insight is a straightforward extension."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Request to Follow
attributes.Definition: Make Following a two-sided operation, so that celebs have implicit limits on the ability of fans to follow them.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661641487,"blocks":[{"id":"DcV7MlUteV","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Just like in only reciprocal subscriptions, the structure of subscriptions imposes implicit limitations on their usage. Imposing limitations on the capacity of subscriptions to grow can limit influencer-type dynamics, encouraging users to share and spread ideas, without encouraging the winner-take-all, attention-above-everything dynamics that emerge when orders of magnitude distinguish the reach and influence of some users over others."}},{"id":"1zeP6NYZNL","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"One idea long this dimension is to require that people \"accept\" follow requests. This wouldn't quite be all-subscriptions-reciprocal, since it would still allow for unidirectional subscriptions. However, even forcing a user to tap an \"accept\" button over and over would seriously pose a limit on their capacity to grow their following. The most dedicated influencers might accept 1000 or even 10,000 \"follow requests\" from potential followers. But it's hard to imagine users ever overcoming this friction to expand into the echelons of reach that social media influencers enjoy and utilize in today's winner-take-all attention economy."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Subscriptions
attributes.Definition: Allows a user to request they receive another channel's novel content.

attributes.Title: Affinity

attributes.Title: Two-Factor Payment Identification
attributes.Definition: Require one user to specify multiple pieces of information about anothother user to send them a payment.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661551249,"blocks":[{"id":"rUTlU3cn3y","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Digital payments between users without affinity presents a problem for platforms. While in many cases this is innocuous, just two new folks exchanging goods or services, it is also a common signal of a scam, impersonation, or just a user mistyping the handle of another user."}},{"id":"l8hEQVNXhu","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"To help guard against this, payment platforms can (and often have) implemented \"two-factor identification - requiring users to specify two kinds of information about the person they're sending the money to. In cases of impersonation, this can help them realize that they're being duped. In cases of error, it can prevent them from sending money to the wrong person. In cases of scams, it can give the user a second to consider how well they know the person they're sending the money to (\"should I be sending $500 to someone who I don't know their phone number?\")."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Payments
attributes.Definition: The capacity for users to initiate outgoing payments or receive incoming ones.

attributes.Title: Scams
attributes.Definition: Commercial offerings that intentionally deceive their participants.

attributes.Title: Speedbump
attributes.Definition: A temporary obstacle created to make undesired behavior less frequent, through difficulty or reconsideration.

attributes.Title: Require unleaked passwords
attributes.Definition: During signup, don't allow users to use a password that has been included in a leaked dataset.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661716303,"blocks":[{"id":"TNylDM7WaE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Despite decades of warnings, tons of people still reuse passwords across multiple sites. If this is you, please invest in a password manager right now - it is the single most important thing you can do for your online security."}},{"id":"5UinkDPdmH","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Password reuse is a problem because there is a steady drum-beat of security breaches across the web, many sites that collect username and password don't salt the passwords properly (fun math stuff, don't worry about it), and as a result, there are huge troves of username + password pairs out there on the dark web, easy for a hacker to use to try to gain access to the user's account on other sites."}},{"id":"V37Vb0NPVQ","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Note: even if a platform has perfect security themselves, when their users create an account with a reused password, they are susceptible to impersonation and account hijacking on the platform. "}},{"id":"nkX84goKC-","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"A solution to this problem could be to prevent users from signing up using any password that has been found on the dark web at all. It would force users to come up with truly unique passwords, and help steer them (maybe with explicit nudges) toward using a password generator."}},{"id":"BbLCzyYo2i","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This also seems like a good place for regulation. Government could set up standardized protocols for checking whether a password has previously been leaked, as well as centralizing the maintenance of the collection of leaked passwords, either directly, or through the creation of standards."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Posting Limits
attributes.Definition: Limit the volume of information a user can generate in a day.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661123900,"blocks":[{"id":"UISg3zGeEM","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This is a catch-all approach that stems from a simple principle: one user generating a ton more data than other users tends to be a signal of abuse. What that abuse is varies widely, but the trend is broadly applicable: abuse most often happens in the tails of the distribution of activity."}},{"id":"15DIWB6vnP","type":"list","data":{"style":"unordered","items":["A user uploading way larger files than others is much more likely to be involved in Copyright Infringement or Resource Abuse","A user messaging way more people than average is much more likely to be generating content perceived as Spam, or recruiting for an MLM.","A user leaving way more comments than average is much more likely to be harassing another user."]}},{"id":"oVEeYPLUv_","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In each of these cases, the volume can't (by itself) tell the platform what the user is doing, but it is a technical signal that can both (a)  serve as an automatic trigger for human review (b) indicate that a small number of users are consuming a disproportionate share of the resources/space on a platform. "}},{"id":"MO-G8IPcTn","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Setting limits on content creation, even very high ones, can help reduce the liklihood of abuses like these occurring, by putting an upper limit on the platform's usefulness for the motivations of the actor behind each. "}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Crowdsourced Metadata
attributes.Definition: Allow users limited access to content metadata, and enable them to highlight this on the posts of other users.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699661260356,"blocks":[{"id":"RIHadIY7Nd","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Some forms of abuse require platform-level views and metrics to identify. Platforms have access to many metrics on individual pieces of content that regular users have no insight into, as well as evaluations of the standard ranges for those metrics across the full platform. In most cases, platforms seek to keep this information to themselves - disclosing it could risk shedding too much light on platform operations and mechanisms, not to mention the privacy risks involved."}},{"id":"5ZyHVb7Wnt","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"However, in some cases, platforms should consider allowing users to highlight these metrics to help contextualize information on the platform. Ex:"}},{"id":"VKdJ3Xhybb","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["\"This user exclusively logs in from Russia\" would be a helpful disclosure on the comments of a user discussing US politics.","\"This file was first seen on the internet six months ago\" would be a useful piece of information to show on a video purporting to be from a new armed conflict.","\"This meme was first posted by user @ImANazi\" would be a helpful piece of context to understand the motivating ideology of the meme."]}},{"id":"Ts303zxlhK","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Importantly, in each of these cases, the context that the platform is providing is purely technical in nature, and is typically already collected by most major platforms. Adding the option for users to investigate questions of this kind doesn't require the platform to become an arbiter of truth, just a steward of technical metadata."}},{"id":"xe3SD8DQUq","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This broad category of intervention would allow users more visibility into the metadata that platforms collect, and could additionally allow them to crowdsource or highlight this information to other users. Similar to how Crowdsourced Annotations can work, users could pull out pieces of metadata that help them better situate the idea in context."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Three Insult Rule
attributes.Definition: Rather than looking at whether individual pieces of content constitute harassment, consider patterns of behavior.
attributes.Description:
{"time":1699661525500,"blocks":[{"id":"3bpCbCWJBi","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Content Moderation as typically conceived of is circumscribed by the \"four corners of the content\" - it tries to apply a set of rules to a piece of content, and test whether or not (or to what degree) the content violates those rules."}},{"id":"OUFo7upwcK","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This approach is limited in its capacity to capture patterns of behavior that constitute abrogation of community standards, but fail to do so in the context of a single piece of reportable content. Particularly in the context of harassment + cyber-bullying, this poses a headache for platforms trying to formalize and standardize their treatment of content, while respecting and serving user expectations. "}},{"id":"1Ttg__SRiG","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"One approach to solving this problem is the so-called \"Three Insult Rule\" that Facebook has used. From that Lawfare Article:

\"The rule required the presence of multiple mild insults in a post (or across several posts) before Twitter would step in. The rationale behind the rule was to avoid arbitrating schoolyard disputes between users; the companys top-down content moderation procedures would only kick in past a certain point of hostility. The three-insult rule was one of hundreds of granular guidelines arbitrating the finer points of online speecha set of detailed guidelines that exist at nearly every tech company but only rarely see the light of day.\"
"}},{"id":"F0iFhT50rg","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While it is certainly not worth going into the myriad of small rules like this one that platforms can implement, it's an important category of intervention to call out one facet of this kind of pattern. Signals along one dimension (content) can be aggregated into signals along other dimensions (users) that help achieve better outcomes. This isn't unidirectional, and it isn't limited to these two classes of signals."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Deprioritize User Identity
attributes.Definition: In platforms where the identity of the participants isn't central, omit it.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699668084803,"blocks":[{"id":"ASRvD5ay0B","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"While many platforms intentionally facilitate exchange, coordination, and communication of users in ways where identity is a central part of the exchange (dating platforms for example), on other forms of online interaction, particularly commerce, the interaction need not center (or even reference) user identity in order to fulfill its core function. This is most common in purely commercial exchanges online, like short term housing rentals, peer to peer taxi services, job boards, or marketplaces for goods or services. "}},{"id":"RaciWbVayt","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"Since the capability of discerning identity characteristics is a prerequisite for online discrimination or sexual harassment, platforms that don't have identity as a core part of their function should consider how they can limit users' ability to represent themselves on the platform. De-emphasizing identity covers a range of possible interventions, like the omission of features like profile pictures, using users' initials rather than names, or at one extreme, omitting users' ability to represent their identity at all. Removing emphasis from identity can better center focus on the core value proposition of platforms - enabling more uniform and distraction-free access to the services that platforms enable."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

attributes.Title: Identity
attributes.Definition: Individuals' ability to represent themselves in a digital space.

attributes.Title: Hide Interaction Counts
attributes.Definition: Foster authentic interaction by making numerical properties less central.
attributes.Description: {"time":1699668152228,"blocks":[{"id":"is5eq4QhcE","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In online platforms that seek to digitize or augment forms of real world human to human connection (like social networks, review sites, or dating sites), centering the numerical elements that are used to estimate quality can easily distract from the interpersonal component of the interaction."}},{"id":"vHc-OnwoXw","type":"list","data":{"style":"ordered","items":["Folks will often focus on how many \"likes\" posts get over the content of the post.","After referencing a rating site, people use phrases like \"it has 4.8 stars\" to describe reviews, rather than \"people seem to really like their paella\".","On a dating site, match percentages can skew a user's perception of a potential date, encouraging them to reconsider an \"good\" match, and quickly dismiss a \"bad\" one."]}},{"id":"wFGDV3vh0z","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In each of these examples, the platform records a metric in order to be able to predict with better fidelity what the user will like - a metric that aligns with the aims of the user: Likes are a way to tell the algorithm to show the post to more people, ratings are a way to help sort or recommend restaurants, match percentages are calculated to help the dating site figure out who to show you next."}},{"id":"sBOHFxs6ET","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"However, in each of these examples showing the user the numerical rating isn't required for it to be of value to them, and the display of the numerical representation has the likely effect of skewing the user's perception away from the interpersonal component of the interaction, toward some platform defined, all-flattening metric."}},{"id":"6EWW9dlpgL","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"In many such situations, users would be better served by the platform still computing these scores, but then only displaying them in contexts where they serve some clear functional purpose, and omitting them in other contexts where their removal can increase the user's focus on their task. "}},{"id":"QedRnFLJwI","type":"paragraph","data":{"text":"This would have the side-effect of making a wide swathe of issues we typically think of as trust and safety issues (from Addiction to Review Bombing to Discrimination to Online Shaming to...) far less acute. It is hard to find an intervention that would so radically change the dynamics and cultures of online spaces as the small little change of hiding a number."}}],"version":"2.23.2"}

Allowing users more control over their time on platform can help users escape their rabbit holes.
In many online contexts, sharing a location is never expected, so blocking it prevents unexpected platform uses.
Sensitive data should have different thresholds for takedown. Allowing users narrow censorship can minimize the efficacy of doxxing, and dissuade users from doing it.

attributes.Title: Violent and Criminal Behavior: Sexual Exploitation
attributes.Definition: Depicting, threatening, or enabling sexual violence or exploitation.

attributes.Title: Sextortion
attributes.Definition: Using blackmail or threats to coerce a victim into providing sexual images or favors.

attributes.Title: Non-consensual Explicit Imagery
attributes.Definition: Distribution of sexual imagery without the authorization of the person depicted.

attributes.Title: Violent and Criminal Behavior: Human Exploitation
attributes.Definition: Engaging in or enabling the sale, enslavement, or coercion of people  into laborious, dangerous, or illegal actions.

attributes.Title: Blackmail
attributes.Definition: Using threats of disclosure to coerce a victim.

attributes.Title: Community-Specific Rules: Content Limitation
attributes.Definition: Rules on where and how certain topics can be discussed.

attributes.Title: Multi Level Marketing
attributes.Definition: Sales organizations that grow primarily through an expansion in membership.

attributes.Title: Community-Specific Rules: Format
attributes.Definition: Rules on the form of content, often for clarity, organization, or technical limitations.

attributes.Title: Resource Abuse
attributes.Definition: Creating generalized network, storage, or compute resources by misusing low-cost resources on the open internet.

attributes.Title: Deceptive & Fraudulent Behavior: Defamation
attributes.Definition: Damaging the good reputation of others.

attributes.Title: Deceptive & Fraudulent Behavior: Fraud
attributes.Definition: Attempting to wrongfully or criminally deceive for financial benefit, or encouraging / supporting others to do so.

attributes.Title: Scams
attributes.Definition: Commercial offerings that intentionally deceive their participants.

attributes.Title: Ad Fraud
attributes.Definition: Boosting advertising income through fraudulent user activity.

attributes.Title: Deceptive & Fraudulent Behavior: Cybersecurity
attributes.Definition: Attempting to compromise accounts or other sensitive information.

attributes.Title: Phishing
attributes.Definition: Using impersonation to trick a victim into revealing sensitive information.

attributes.Title: Deceptive & Fraudulent Behavior: Impersonation
attributes.Definition: Taking over the identity of another user or group.

attributes.Title: Identity Theft
attributes.Definition: Stealing credentials or other personal information, typically for financial impersonation.

attributes.Title: Account Hijacking
attributes.Definition: Unauthorized takeover of someone else's account.

attributes.Title: Impersonation
attributes.Definition: Deceptively assuming the identity of a real person.

attributes.Title: Catfishing
attributes.Definition: Intentionally deceiving others about who you are, typically on dating platforms.

attributes.Title: Deceptive & Fraudulent Behavior: Intellectual Property
attributes.Definition: Using trademarks or copyright protected content without permission.

attributes.Title: Copyright/IP Infringement
attributes.Definition: Unauthorized use, reproduction or distribution of works covered by intellectual property protections.

attributes.Title: Scaled Abuse: Spam
attributes.Definition: Unsolicited and unwanted content / messaging, particularly commercial advertising, generated at scale.

attributes.Title: Spam
attributes.Definition: Unsolicited solicitations with commercial or promotional intent.

attributes.Title: Scaled Abuse: Malware
attributes.Definition: Links to malicious software that can negatively affect users.

attributes.Title: Malware
attributes.Definition: Software built to gain unauthorized access to computers.

attributes.Title: Ransomware
attributes.Definition: Malware which holds a user's data as a hostage until a ransom is paid.

attributes.Title: Scaled Abuse: Inauthentic Behavior
attributes.Definition: Using fake accounts to deceive or manipulate users.

attributes.Title: Coordinated Inauthentic Activity
attributes.Definition: Manipulating online platforms through coordinated creation of inaccurate data.

attributes.Title: None
attributes.Definition: Not captured by the TSPA taxonomy.

attributes.Title: Filter Bubbles
attributes.Definition: Algorithmically driven content selection that prioritizes content that aligns with the user's prior ideas.

attributes.Title: Confirmation Bias
attributes.Definition: The tendency to seek and prioritize information that aligns with preexisting beliefs.

attributes.Title: Profile Building
attributes.Definition: Collecting and collating information about a user from across the internet in order to create a representational model of their interests and attitudes.

attributes.Title: Addiction
attributes.Definition: Employing strategies to encourage users to engage with more frequency and investment than the user would prefer.

attributes.Title: Echo Chamber
attributes.Definition: The unconscious tendency for people to surround themselves with media that align with their existing views.

attributes.Title: Discrimination
attributes.Definition: Targeting or excluding individuals in online spaces based on a protected or immutable characteristic.

attributes.Title: Political Misinformation
attributes.Definition: Spreading false or misleading information to influence political attitudes and outcomes.

attributes.Title: Squatting
attributes.Definition: Collecting high value usernames for resale, ransom or confusion, rather than for use.

attributes.Title: Manipulated Media / Deep Fakes
attributes.Definition: Inauthentic media that passes itself off as authentic.

attributes.Title: Account Resale
attributes.Definition: Selling stolen account credentials to enable users to assume new identities.

attributes.Title: Feedback bombing
attributes.Definition: Attempting to manipulate perception of an entity through large volumes of inauthentic feedback.

attributes.Title: Election Misinformation
attributes.Definition: Incorrect information about the mechanics of an election that can cause viewers to be disenfranchised.

attributes.Title: Promoting Illegal Activity
attributes.Definition: Advocating or facilitating actions that are explicitly prohibited by law.

attributes.Title: Artificial Intimacy
attributes.Definition: The creation of an a unidirectional emotional connection, often for manipulation.

attributes.Title: Trolling
attributes.Definition: Posting disingenuous provocative messages to intentional elicit emotional reactions.

attributes.Title: User Safety: Suicide and Self Harm
attributes.Definition: Content in which a person is harming or threatening to harm themselves or enabling / encouraging others to do so.

attributes.Title: Self-Harm Amplification
attributes.Definition: The exacerbation and normalization of self-destructive behavior.

attributes.Title: User Safety: Harassment and Bullying
attributes.Definition: Intimidating, degrading, or humiliating a specific individual or group of people.

attributes.Title: Harassment / Cyberbullying
attributes.Definition: Unwanted and repeated behavior that threatens, annoys, or intimidates a victim.

attributes.Title: Online Shaming
attributes.Definition: Using the internet to publicly shame or ridicule.

attributes.Title: Location Misuse
attributes.Definition: Malicious use of geo-location data to stalk, harass, or harm.

attributes.Title: Stalking
attributes.Definition: Persistent, unwanted surveillance of an individual, often causing fear and distress.

attributes.Title: Doxxing
attributes.Definition: Divulging someone's personal information, like location, in order to harass them.

attributes.Title: Swatting
attributes.Definition: Making false reports to emergency services in order to bring a victim into confrontation with law enforcement.

attributes.Title: User Safety: Dangerous Misinformation and Endangerment
attributes.Definition: Content / behavior that might cause a user to unintentionally cause harm to themselves or others.

attributes.Title: Incentivizing Dangerous Behavior
attributes.Definition: Creating dynamics in which dangerous activity is glorified and implicitly encouraged.

attributes.Title: Health Misinformation
attributes.Definition: Inaccurate claims, unsupported opinions or conspiracy theories about health that cause personal and public health harms.

attributes.Title: Offensive & Objectionable Content: Hateful Content
attributes.Definition: Expressing or encouraging hatred, contempt, discrimination, or violence against specific groups based on protected classes which includes factors such as race, religion, gender, or sexual orientation.

attributes.Title: Hate Speech
attributes.Definition: Explicitly advocating violence, discrimination, or prejudice toward individuals or groups based on immutable characteristics.

attributes.Title: Offensive & Objectionable Content: Graphic and Violent Content
attributes.Definition: Depictions of deaths, injuries, and other violent acts that are likely to shock, upset, or offend.

attributes.Title: Offensive & Objectionable Content: Nudity and Sexual Activity
attributes.Definition: Depicting, soliciting, or offering non-commercial sex acts or adult nudity

attributes.Title: Unwelcome Sexual Advances
attributes.Definition: When a user initiates a sexual or romantic exchange with another outside of a reasonable context.

attributes.Title: Regulated Goods and Services: Regulated Goods
attributes.Definition: Sale / trade of goods which are generally regulated or banned.

attributes.Title: Regulated Goods and Services: Regulated Services
attributes.Definition: Sale / trade of services which are generally regulated or banned.

attributes.Title: Money Laundering
attributes.Definition: Disguising the origins of illegally obtained funds to make them appear legitimate.

attributes.Title: Regulated Goods and Services: Commercial Sexual Activity
attributes.Definition: Depicting, solicitings, or offering sex acts or adult nudity in exchange for money.

attributes.Title: Violent and Criminal Behavior: Dangerous and Criminal Organizations
attributes.Definition: The presence of criminal or otherwise dangerous groups and their members, and content / behavior that supports such groups.

attributes.Title: Violent Extremism
attributes.Definition: Content that supports motivated acts of violence as means to achieve political, religious, or social objectives.

attributes.Title: Violent and Criminal Behavior: Violence
attributes.Definition: Directly threatening, supporting, or enabling acts of physical violence.

attributes.Title: Violent and Criminal Behavior: Child Abuse and Nudity
attributes.Definition: Depicting or engaging in the abuse or exploitation of children.

attributes.Title: Child Sexual Abuse Imagery
attributes.Definition: Media that depicts or encourages the sexual exploitation of children.

attributes.Title: Grooming
attributes.Definition: The deliberate development of emotional connection with a minor as a means to manipulate and exploit them.
